documents.title: Order Denying Burnett Defendants' Motion To Transfer
documents.text:
Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 115   Filed 07/15/14   Page 1 of 8 PageID #:  2313
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
BEAUMONT DIVISION 
 
BIJU MAKRUKKATTU JOSEPH, et al.  ' 
  ' 
v.    '    1:13-CV-324 
  ' 
SIGNAL INTERNATIONAL L.L.C.,   ' 
et al.               ' 
 
ORDER DENYING BURNETT DEFENDANTSโ MOTION TO TRANSFER  
  Pending before the court is a โMotion to Transfer Venue and Memorandum in Supportโ 
(Doc. No. 39), filed by Malvern C. Burnett, the Law Offices of Malvern C. Burnett, A.P.C., and 
Gulf Coast Immigration Law Center, L.L.C (โthe Burnett Defendantsโ).  Having considered the 
pending motion and the corresponding response (Doc. No. 52), reply (Doc. No. 53), and sur-reply 
(Doc. No. 58), the court denies the motion because there is not a substantial overlap between the 
instant suit and Kurian David et al. v. Signal, Intโl, L.L.C. et al., the first filed suit.  See Civ. A. 
No. 08-1220 (E.D. La.). 
I.  Background 
A.  Procedural Background 
  On March 7, 2008, twelve individuals who were allegedly trafficked into the United States 
filed a putative class action against the Defendants in the Eastern District of Louisiana asserting 
trafficking, RICO, civil rights, and state law contract and fraud claims.1  That Court denied class 
                                                 
  1.  The District Court has not ruled on the collective action FLSA claims in the David case, which include 
opt-ins by the Plaintiffs in this case.  (Doc. No. 52, p. 9.) 
 
 
Page 1 of 8 
 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 115   Filed 07/15/14   Page 2 of 8 PageID #:  2314
certification;2 and, as a result of this ruling, the Plaintiffs in the instant action filed suit in this 
District, where they were allegedly subjected to deplorable working conditions at a Signal facility 
in Orange, Texas.  (Doc. No. 64.)  On May 21, 2013, the Plaintiffs filed a complaint in this court 
against the following Defendants: the Burnett Defendants, Signal International L.L.C., Signal 
International, Inc., Signal International Texas, G.P., Signal International Texas, L.P. (collectively 
referred to as โSignalโ), Indo-Amerisoft L.L.C., Kurella Rao, J&M Associates, Inc. of Mississippi, 
Billy R. Wilks, J&M Marine & Industrial, L.L.C., Global Resources, Inc., Michael Pol, Sachin 
Dewan,  and  Dewan  Consultants  PVT.  LTD.  (a/k/a  Medtech  Consultants).    The  Burnett 
Defendants consist of Malvern C. Burnett and his two corporations: Gulf Coast Immigration Law 
Center, L.L.C. and Law Offices of Malvern C. Burnett, A.P.C.  The Plaintiffs allege that some or 
all of the Defendants violated the following federal statutes: 1) The Trafficking Victims Protection 
Reauthorization Act of 2003; 2) Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act; 3) The Civil 
Rights act of 1866; and 4) The Ku Klux Klan Act of 1871.  (Id.)  In addition, the Plaintiffs bring 
state law fraud, negligent misrepresentation and breach of contract claims against all of the 
Defendants.  (Id.)  On September 3, 2013, the Burnett Defendants filed the pending motion to 
transfer venue.  (Doc. No. 39.)   
                                                 
  2.  David v. Signal Intโl, LLC, Civ. A. No. 08-1220, 2012 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 114247, at *129 (E.D. La. Jan. 
3, 2012). 
 
Page 2 of 8 
 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 115   Filed 07/15/14   Page 3 of 8 PageID #:  2315
B.  Factual Background    
  In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, approximately 590 men, including the Plaintiffs, 
were allegedly trafficked into the United States through the federal governmentโs H-2B guest 
worker program to provide services to the Signal Defendants.  (Doc. No. 64, p. 2.)  The Plaintiffs 
claim they were lured to work for Signal through the fraudulent promise of legal and permanent 
work-based  immigration  to  the  United  States  for  themselves  and  their  families.   (Id.)   
Subsequently, after coming to the United States, the Plaintiffs were allegedly subjected to forced 
labor and other serious abuses at Signal operations in Orange, Texas.  (Id.)   
II.  Jurisdiction  
  The Plaintiffs seek recovery pursuant to several federal statutes.  For actions brought 
under these statutory provisions, the court has subject-matter jurisdiction predicated upon federal 
question jurisdiction.  See 28 U.S.C. ยง 1331; 29 U.S.C. ยง 216(b).  For the state law causes of 
action, the court has subject-matter jurisdiction predicated upon supplemental jurisdiction.  See 
28 U.S.C. ยง 1367(a).  Venue is proper because the events giving rise to the above claims occurred 
within the confines of this District.  See 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391.  
III.  First to File Rule  
  The Burnett Defendants  move to transfer the instant case to the Eastern District of 
Louisiana pursuant to the First-Filed Doctrine.  (Doc. No. 39, p. 1.)  โUnder the first-to-file rule, 
when related cases are pending before two federal courts, the court in which the case was last filed 
may refuse to hear it if the issues raised by the cases substantially overlap.โ  Intโl Fid. Ins. Co. v. 
Sweet Little Mexico Corp., 665 F.3d 671, 677 (5th Cir. 2011) (quoting Cadle Co. v. Whataburger 
 
Page 3 of 8 
 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 115   Filed 07/15/14   Page 4 of 8 PageID #:  2316
of Alice, Inc., 174 F.3d 599, 603 (5th Cir. 1999)).  โThe first-to-file rule is a discretionary 
doctrine.โ Jones v. Xerox Commercial Solutions, LLC, CIV. A. No. H-13-0650, 2013 WL 
3245957, at *2 (S.D. Tex. June 26, 2013) (quoting Cadle Co., 174 F.3d at 603).  The rule is 
utilized โto avoid the waste of duplication, to avoid rulings which may trench upon the authority of 
sister courts, and to avoid piecemeal resolution of issues that call for a uniform result.โ  Save 
Power Ltd. v. Syntek Fin. Corp., 121 F.3d 947, 950 (5th Cir. 1997).  The party wishing to transfer 
the case has the burden to prove that transfer is warranted.  Jones, 2013 WL 3245957, at *2 (citing 
SanofiโAventis Deutschland GmbH v. Novo Nordisk, Inc., 614 F. Supp. 2d 772, 777 n. 5 (E.D. 
Tex. 2009); VCode Holdings, Inc. v. Cognex Corp., No. 2:07โcvโ138, 2007 WL 2238054, at *2 
(E.D. Tex. Aug. 3, 2007); Buckalew v. Celanese, LTD., No. Gโ05โ315, 2005 WL 2266619, at *1 
(S.D. Tex. Sept. 16, 2005)).   
  โIn deciding whether to apply the first-to-file rule, the Court must resolve two questions: 
(1) are the two pending actions so duplicative or do they involve such substantially similar issues 
that one court should decide the subject matter of both actions, and if so, (2) which of the two 
courts  should  take  the  case.โ    Datamize,  Inc.  v.  Fid.  Brokerage  Servs.,  LLC,  No. 
2:03-CV-321-DF, 2004 WL 1683171, at *3 (E.D. Tex. Apr. 22, 2004) (citing Texas Instruments v. 
Micron Semiconductor, 815 F. Supp. 994, 997 (E.D. Tex. 1993)).  โThe first-to-file rule does not 
require that cases be identical, but merely that there is a substantial overlap in issues and parties.โ  
White v. Peco Foods, Inc., 546 F. Supp. 2d 339, 342 (S.D. Miss. 2008).   
 
Page 4 of 8 
 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 115   Filed 07/15/14   Page 5 of 8 PageID #:  2317
IV.  Analysis 
  The Burnett Defendants argue there is substantial overlap between the instant case and the 
first filed case, David.  (Doc. No. 39, p. 1.)  While there are similarities in the two cases, the court 
finds that the two cases do not involve such substantially similar parties and issues that one court 
should decide the subject matter of both actions. 
A.  Parties 
  There is some overlap between the parties in David and the instant case, but it is not 
substantial.  While all of the Plaintiffs in the instant suit are also plaintiffs in David, as explained 
below, they are only asserting FLSA claims in David, which they do not assert here.3  (Doc. No. 
52, p. 9.)  Conversely, none of the David plaintiffs asserting non-FLSA claims are parties in the 
instant case.  (Id.)  The David defendants and the Defendants in this suit are not completely 
identical, but for purposes of this analysis, the court finds that the difference is insignificant.  
While the first-to-file rule does not require identical parties, see Save Power Ltd., 121 F.3d at 950, 
โthe fact that the parties are different cuts against an argument for substantial overlap.โ  Jones, 
2013 WL 3245957, at *4.   
B.  Claims 
  Although the first-to-file rule also does not require the issues to completely overlap, โthe 
cases should be more than merely related to support a motion to transfer when venue is otherwise 
appropriate.โ  Buckalew v. Celanese, Ltd., CIV. A. No. G-05-315, 2005 WL 2266619, at *2 (S.D. 
                                                 
3.  Even if the Plaintiffs in this case were at one point putative class members in the David class action 
litigation, they were never parties since the class was never certified.  See Smith v. Bayer Corp., 131 S. Ct. 2368, 
2379 (2011) (holding that it is erroneous to believe a nonnamed class member is a party to class action litigation before 
the class is certified, or if certification is ultimately denied). 
 
 
Page 5 of 8 
 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 115   Filed 07/15/14   Page 6 of 8 PageID #:  2318
Tex. Sept. 16, 2005).  The instant suit and David are related to the extent that all of the claims 
asserted in this suit are also asserted by the different David Plaintiffs.  However, there is not 
substantial overlap among the claims in both suits.  As the District Court established in its opinion 
denying the Plaintiffsโ motion for class certification in David, each of the Plaintiffsโ claims require 
individualized proof as it pertains to that particular Plaintiff.  David v. Signal Intโl, LLC, Civ. A. 
No. 08-1220, 2012 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 114247, at *129 (E.D. La. Jan. 3, 2012).  Thus, not only are 
each of the individual Plaintiffsโ forced labor, trafficking, RICO and civil rights claims different 
from one another in this suit, as explained below, they are entirely different from their pending 
FLSA claims in David.  Therefore, the issues presented by the Plaintiffs here cannot be resolved 
in the David suit.  W. Gulf Mar. Assโn v. ILA Deep Sea Local 24, S. Atl. & Gulf Coast Dist. of 
ILA, AFL-CIO, 751 F.2d 721, 729 (5th Cir. 1985) (โ. . . a district court may dismiss an action 
where the issues presented can be resolved in an earlier-filed action pending in another district 
court.โ).  The Plaintiffsโ claims in the instant case also rely heavily on the alleged abuses and poor 
working conditions at the Signal facility in Orange, Texas.  Logically, the conditions experienced 
by the Plaintiffs in this case will be different than those experienced by a majority of the David 
Plaintiffs who were housed in Signalโs Pascagoula, Mississippi facility.  (Doc. No. 32, Exh. 2, pp. 
5-7.)4 
                                                 
  4.  Burnett asserts in his motion to transfer: โ[a]ttached hereto as Exhibit 1 is the entire Complaint filed in 
David.โ  (Doc. No. 39, p. 2.)  However Burnett did not attach the complaint as an exhibit to his motion when it was 
filed.  Nonetheless, Burnett did attach the David complaint to his motion to dismiss (Doc. No. 32, Exh. 2), which the 
court considered.  
 
Page 6 of 8 
 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 115   Filed 07/15/14   Page 7 of 8 PageID #:  2319
  1.  Forced Labor and Trafficking 
  The  success  of  each  Plaintiffโs  forced  labor  and  trafficking  claims  is  dependent  on 
individualized factors.  The question in a forced labor case is โwhether Defendantsโ coercive 
conduct was such that it could overcome the will of the victim so as to make him render his labor 
involuntary.โ  David, 2012 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 114247 at 77.  โThis question cannot be answered 
via  generalized  class-wide  proof  but  rather  must  be  answered  individually  based  upon 
individualized proof.โ  Id.  Similarly, with trafficking, โindividual issues will play a significant 
partโ because involuntary servitude is an essential element of the claim.  Id. at 80-81.   
  2.  RICO Claims 
  The success of each Plaintiffโs RICO claim is also based on each individualโs experience 
because the Plaintiff will be โrequired to prove that the [Defendants] committed the predicate acts 
upon which they rely for the pattern of racketeering activity.โ  Id. at 92.  As stated above, proof 
of the predicate acts of trafficking and forced labor are โall premised on coercionโ and โcannot be 
made without resort to individualized proof.โ  Id.  Additionally, in order to prove the fraud-based 
predicate acts, each Plaintiff will โhave to prove first-party reliance on the alleged fraud that was 
directed at them,โ because โthe question of individual reliance [is] paramount to resolving whether 
Plaintiffsโ injuries were caused by a RICO violation.โ  Id. at 105-06. 
  3.  Violations of the Ku Klux Klan Act of 1871 
  The Plaintiffs allege that the Burnett Defendants violated the Ku Klux Klan Act of 1971 by 
violating their right to be free from โforced labor, involuntary servitude, and trafficking in 
persons.โ  (Doc. No. 64, p. 65.)  Forced labor, involuntary servitude, and trafficking all include 
 
Page 7 of 8 
 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 115   Filed 07/15/14   Page 8 of 8 PageID #:  2320
an element of coercion, which requires an individualized analysis of each Plaintiffโs situation, as 
stated above.  David, 2012 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 114247, at *128.   
  As one can easily discern, none of the above causes of action involve substantially similar 
issues to the Plaintiffsโ FLSA claims pending in David, which include claims of violating the 
federally mandated minimum wage laws.  The proof required for the FLSA claims and the 
remedies sought are distinct from the proof and remedies at issue in the instant matter.  Given that 
there is not a substantial overlap of the claims between the David litigation and this case, and with 
the exception of the Plaintiffsโ FLSA claims in David, none of the Plaintiffs in the instant suit and 
David overlap, the courtโs denial of the Burnett Defendantsโ motion to transfer will not result in 
โpiecemeal resolution of issues that call for a uniform result.โ  Save Power Ltd. v. Syntek Fin. 
Corp., 121 F.3d 947, 950 (5th Cir. 1997).   
V.  Conclusion 
 
  The court finds that the instant suit does not substantially overlap with the first-filed suit, 
David.  Accordingly, the Burnett Defendantsโ โMotion to Transfer Venue and Memorandum in 
Supportโ (Doc. No. 39) is DENIED. 
 
SIGNED this 14th day of July, 2014.
   
__________________________________________________
Zaacckk HHaawwtthhoorrnn
United States Magistrate Judge
 
Page 8 of 8

documents.title: Order Severing and Transferring Signal's Cross-Claims to the Eastern District of Lousiana
documents.text:
Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 205   Filed 12/08/14   Page 1 of 6 PageID #:  7412
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
BEAUMONT DIVISION 
 
BIJU MARKUKKATTU JOSEPH, et al.  ' 
  ' 
v.    '    1:13-CV-324 
  ' 
SIGNAL INTERNATIONAL L.L.C.,   ' 
et al.  ' 
 
ORDER SEVERING AND TRANSFERRING SIGNALโS CROSS-CLAIMS  
TO THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF LOUISIANA 
 
This case is assigned to the Honorable Ron Clark, United States District Judge, and is 
referred to the undersigned United States magistrate judge for all pretrial matters.  (Doc. No. 4.)  
Pending before the undersigned is the โMotion to Defer Signalโs Cross Claim[s] or in the 
Alternative to Transfer Venue of Signalโs Cross Claim[s] Pursuant to the First-Filed Ruleโ (Doc. 
No. 167) filed by Defendants Malvern C. Burnett, Malvern C. Burnett A.P.C., and the Gulf Coast 
Immigration Center, L.L.C. (collectively, โBurnettโ).  The certificate of conference states that 
โSignal has no objection to the filing of the motion, but has not determined, as yet, its position on 
the merits of the motion itself . . . .โ (Id. at p. 12.)  It was not indicated whether any other party 
opposed the motion.  However, the time for responding to Burnettโs motion has passed and no 
objections were filed.  Accordingly, the undersigned considers the motion unopposed.  See 
Local Rule CV-7(d) (โIn the event that a party fails to oppose a motion in the manner prescribed 
herein, the court will assume that the party has no objection.โ).  After reviewing Burnettโs motion 
and the applicable authorities, the undersigned finds that Burnettโs motion should be granted in 
part and that Signalโs cross-claims should be severed from the main action and transferred to the 
Eastern District of Louisiana.   
 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 205   Filed 12/08/14   Page 2 of 6 PageID #:  7413
I. Background 
On March 7, 2008, a putative class action was filed in the Eastern District of Louisiana on 
behalf of over five hundred plaintiffs who were allegedly victims of human trafficking.  (See Doc. 
No. 1, David v. Signal Intโl, L.L.C., No. 2:08-1220 (E.D. La. March 7, 2008)).  The court in 
David denied class certification (as to all claims except the plaintiffsโ FLSA claims), which caused 
the putative class members to file suit in the district where their injuries allegedly occurred.  The 
Plaintiffs in this case filed suit in the Eastern District of Texas because they claim to have suffered 
their injuries at a Signal facility in Orange, Texas.  
Like in David, the Plaintiffs in this case sued numerous defendants.  (See Doc. No. 1); 
(See also Doc. No. 1, David v. Signal Intโl, L.L.C., No. 2:08-1220 (E.D. La. March 7, 2008)) 
(naming twelve defendants).  For convenience, the Plaintiffs grouped the Defendants into four 
categories: โSignalโ (collectively, Signal International, L.L.C., Signal International Texas, G.P., 
Signal  International  Texas,  L.P.,  and  Signal  International,  Inc.),    โRecruiter  Defendants,โ 
(collectively, Global Resources, Inc., Michael Pol, Dewan Consultants Pvt., Ltd., and Sachin 
Dewan), โLegal Facilitator Defendantsโ (collectively, Malvern C. Burnett, Malvern C. Burnett 
A.P.C.,  and  the  Gulf  Coast  Immigration  Center,  L.L.C),  and  โLabor  Broker  Defendantsโ 
(collectively, Indo-Amerisoft, L.L.C., Kurella Rao, J & M Associates of Mississippi, Inc., and 
Billy  R.  Wilks).   Also  common  to  both  cases  are  cross-claims  Signal  filed  against  these 
defendants.  (Doc. No. 164, pp. 59โ78); (Doc. No. 60, David v. Signal,  Intโl, L.L.C., No. 
2:08-1220 (E.D. La. May 9, 2008)).1  Signal filed its cross-claims in the David case in 2008, and 
filed its cross-claims in this case in 2014. 
 
                                                   
1.  In this case, Signal claims that is has suspended its cross-claims against defendant Michael Pol (Doc. No. 
164, p. 59 n. 1), and in David, Signalโs claims against him have been dismissed.  (Doc. No. 1976, David v. Signal, 
Inlโt, L.L.C., No. 2:08-1220 (E.D. La. Dec. 5, 2014)). 
2 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 205   Filed 12/08/14   Page 3 of 6 PageID #:  7414
II. Analysis 
Burnett moves, pursuant to the โfirst-to-file-rule,โ to have this court โโ[p]rophylacticallyโ 
refuse[] to hear Signalโs Cross Claims.โ  (Doc. No. 167, p. 8.)  Alternatively, Burnett requests 
that the undersigned transfer his claims to the Eastern District of Louisiana.  (Id.)  No party filed 
an opposition or response to Burnettโs motion, thus, it is considered unopposed.  See Local Rule 
CV-7(d) (โIn the event that a party fails to oppose a motion in the manner prescribed herein, the 
court  will  assume  that  the  party  has  no  objection.โ).    However,  despite  the  fact  that  the 
undersigned considers Burnettโs motion unopposed, the undersigned finds it prudent to consider 
the merits of Burnettโs motion.       
โUnder the first-to-file rule, when related cases are pending before two federal courts, the 
court in which the case was last filed may refuse to hear it if the issues raised by the cases 
substantially overlap.โ  Intโl Fid. Ins. Co. v. Sweet Little Mex. Corp., 665 F.3d 671, 677 (5th Cir. 
2011) (citation omitted).  โIn such a case, the district court in which the later action was filed may 
dismiss, stay, or transfer the suit in order to avoid duplicative litigation and enforce the principle of 
comity.โ  Carter v. Depโt of Veterans Affairs, 228 F. Appโx 399, 402 (5th Cir. 2007) (per curiam).  
โIn deciding whether to apply the first-to-file rule, the Court must resolve two questions: (1) are 
the two pending actions so duplicative or do they involve such substantially similar issues that one 
court should decide the subject matter of both actions, and if so, (2) which of the two courts should 
take the case.โ  Datamize, Inc. v. Fid. Brokerage Servs., LLC, 2:03-CV-321-DF, 2004 WL 
1683171, at *3 (E.D. Tex. Apr. 22, 2004) (Folsom, J.) (citing Tex. Instruments v. Micron 
Semiconductor, 815 F. Supp. 994, 997 (E.D. Tex. 1993)).  โOnly the first issue is for the 
second-filed court to decide, however, for in this circuit, โ[o]nce the likelihood of a substantial 
overlap between the two suits ha[s] been demonstrated, it [is] no longer up to the [second filed 
3 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 205   Filed 12/08/14   Page 4 of 6 PageID #:  7415
court] to resolve the question of whether both should be allowed to proceed.โโ  Nabors Drilling 
USA, L.P. v. Markow, Walker, P.A., 451 F. Supp. 2d 843, 845 (S.D. Miss. 2006) (alteration in 
original) (quoting Cadle Co. v. Whataburger of Alice, Inc., 174 F.3d 599, 605โ06 (5th Cir. 1999)). 
The undersigned finds that the first prong of the first-to-file rule is satisfied here.  Signalโs 
cross claims in David are not just similar or related to the ones in this caseโthey are identical.  
White v. Peco Foods, Inc., 546 F. Supp. 2d 339, 342 (S.D. Miss. 2008) (โThe first-to-file rule does 
not require that cases be identical, but merely that there is a substantial overlap in issues and 
parties.โ).    First, Signal asserts  cross-claims against the exact  same parties in  both  cases.2  
Compare (Doc. No. 164) with (Doc. No. 60, David v. Signal, Intโl, L.L.C., No. 2:08-1220 (E.D. 
La. May 9, 2008)); see also Save Power Ltd. v. Syntek Fin. Corp., 121 F.3d 947, 951 (5th Cir. 
1997) (โComplete identity of parties is not required for dismissal or transfer of a case filed 
subsequently to a substantially related action.โ).  It is also worth noting that Signalโs cross-claims 
are in no way impacted by the difference in the make-up of the plaintiffs in each case.    
Second, Signal asserted identical cross-claims in each case.  In addition, beyond just 
pleading  the  same  causes  of  action  against  the  same  defendants,  resolution  of  Signalโs 
cross-claims involves the same facts and raises the same issues in both cases.  In contrast, the 
undersigned denied Signalโs and Burnettโs requests to transfer the Plaintiffsโ claims to the Eastern 
District of Louisiana in part because the Plaintiffs in this case worked at a different facility than the 
plaintiffs in David, and therefore, the proof and facts for the claims would differ between the two 
cases.  (Doc. Nos. 74, 115.)  This is not the case for Signalโs cross-claims.  Accordingly, the 
undersigned finds that there is substantial overlap between Signalโs cross-claims in this case and 
those in David. 
                                                   
2. Signal also filed a third-party claim against Zito Companies, L.L.C. that was dismissed.  (Doc. No. 391, 
David v. Signal, Intโl, L.L.C., No. 2:08-1220 (E.D. La. April 7, 2009)). 
4 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 205   Filed 12/08/14   Page 5 of 6 PageID #:  7416
Therefore, the proper course of action is to either transfer, stay, or dismiss Signalโs 
cross-claims.    Burnett  requests  that  this  court  stay  Signalโs  cross  claims  because  โsimply 
declining to hear those Cross Claims herein would be the easiest procedural vehicle to allow 
Signalโs Cross Claims to proceed in the court in which they were first filed.โ  (Doc. No. 167, p. 8.)  
The undersigned, however, perceives no benefit to merely staying these claims.  To do so would 
only invite additional litigation on issue and/or claim preclusion after these claims are decided in 
David.  (Id. at p. 2) (โWhatever disposition may be reached in David on Signalโs Cross Claims 
against Burnett and the other Cross Claim  Defendants  will be res judicata herein.โ).    The 
first-to-file rule was meant to promote efficiency, not create additional substantive issues.   
In the alternative, Burnett requests that the undersigned transfer Signalโs cross-claims to 
the Eastern District of Louisiana.  Because this is the most efficient manner of resolving these 
claims, the undersigned finds that this is the appropriate remedy.  However, in order to transfer 
just Signalโs cross-claims, as opposed the entire case (including the Plaintiffsโ claims), Signalโs 
cross-claims must first be severed from the main case.  Pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil 
Procedure 21, a โtrial court has broad discretion to sever issues to be tried before it.โ  Brunet v. 
United Gas Pipeline Co., 15 F.3d 500, 505 (5th Cir. 1994) (citing FED. R. CIV. P. 21); see also 
United States v. OโNeil, 709 F.2d 361, 366 (5th Cir. 1983) (noting that under Rule 21 a district 
court properly severed a partyโs counterclaims).  The undersigned has authority under Rule 21 to 
sever Signalโs cross-claims even though Burnett did not specifically request such relief.  See 
Brunet, 15 F.3d at 505; United States v. Natโl R.R. Passenger Corp., No. CIV.A 86-1094, 2004 
WL 1335723, at *6 (E.D. Pa. June 15, 2004) (โThus, while neither party has asked this Court to 
sever, Rule 21 permits a court to sever claims sua sponte.โ).   
 
5 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 205   Filed 12/08/14   Page 6 of 6 PageID #:  7417
III. Conclusion 
  For the reasons discussed above, the undersigned GRANTS IN PART Burnettโs โMotion 
to Defer Signalโs Cross Claim or in the Alternative to Transfer Venue of Signalโs Cross Claim 
Pursuant to the First-Filed Rule.โ (Doc. No. 167.)  Accordingly, it is 
  ORDERED that the Clerk of Court is DIRECTED to sever from this action Signalโs 
cross-claims against cross-defendants Malvern C. Burnett, Sachin Dewan, Dewan Consultants 
Pvt., Ltd., Global Resources, Inc. Gulf Coast Immigration Law Center, L.L.C., Indo-Ameri Soft, 
L.L.C., J &M Associates, Inc. of Mississippi, J&M Marine & Industrial, L.L.C., Law Offices of 
Malvern C. Burnett, A.P.C., Michael Pol, Kurella Rao, and Billy R. Wilks; and it is further 
  ORDERED that Signalโs โMotion for Reconsideration of October 20, 2014 Oral Orderโ 
(Doc. No. 199) and Burnettโs response (Doc. No. 201), are part of the severed case; and it is further   
  ORDERED the Clerk of Court shall TRANSFER Signalโs cross-claims against Malvern 
C. Burnett, Sachin Dewan, Dewan Consultants Pvt., Ltd., Global Resources, Inc. Gulf Coast 
Immigration Law Center, L.L.C., Indo-Ameri Soft, L.L.C., J &M Associates, Inc. of Mississippi, 
J&M Marine & Industrial, L.L.C., Law Offices of Malvern C. Burnett, A.P.C., Michael Pol, 
Kurella Rao, and Billy R. Wilks and the motions listed in the preceding paragraph to the Clerk of 
the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.  
 
SIGNED this 8th day of December, 2014.
 
__________________________________________________
Zaacckk HHaawwtthhoorrnn
United States Magistrate Judge
6

documents.title: Order re: Choice of Law
documents.text:
Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 241   Filed 03/06/15   Page 1 of 3 PageID #:  7938
** NOT FOR PRINTED PUBLICATION ** 
 
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
BEAUMONT DIVISION 
 
BIJU MAKRUKKATTU JOSEPH, et al.,  ยง 
  ยง 
  Plaintiffs,  ยง 
  ยง  CIVIL ACTION No. 1-13-CV-324 
v.  ยง 
  ยง  JUDGE RON CLARK 
SIGNAL INTERNATIONAL, LLC, et al.,  ยง 
  ยง  SJF 
  Defendants.   ยง 
 
ORDER RE: CHOICE OF LAW 
 
Defendants Signal International Texas, G.P., Signal International Texas, L.P., Signal 
International, Inc., Signal International, LLC (โSignal Defendantsโ) (Doc. # 225) and Plaintiffs 
(Doc. # 226), have filed briefs on choice of law,  in accordance with the courtโs Order 
(Doc. # 217).1  The parties provided the court with briefing regarding the law to apply to breach 
of contract, fraud, negligent misrepresentation, and agency.  The court finds that the breach of 
contract and fraud claims are governed by Texas law and orders additional briefing on negligent 
misrepresentation and agency.   
I.  Applicable Law 
A federal court sitting in diversity applies substantive law of the forum state.  Bayle v. 
Allstate Ins. Co., 615 F.3d 350, 355 (5th Cir. 2010).  The Texas Supreme Court has adopted the 
Restatement (Second) of Conflict of Laws as the proper expression of its choice-of-law rules.  
DeSantis v. Wackenhut Corp., 793 S.W.2d 670, 677 (Tex. 1990).  Under these rules, unless a 
true conflict exists between the laws of Texas and the laws of the other jurisdiction, Texas law 
                                                 
1 The other Defendants have not filed any briefing on this matter and the deadline set by 
the court for such briefing has past. 
1 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 241   Filed 03/06/15   Page 2 of 3 PageID #:  7939
applies, because it is the forum state.  Flagship Credit Corp .v. Indian Harbor Ins. Co., 481 F. 
Appโx 907, 910 (5th Cir. 2012) (citing Duncan v. Cessna Aircraft Co., 665 S.W.2d 414, 419 
(Tex.1984); Greenberg Traurig of N.Y., P.C. v. Moody, 161 S.W.3d 56, 70 (Tex.App.โHouston 
[14th Dist.] 2004, no pet.)). 
II.  Analysis 
A.  Breach of Contract and Fraud Claims 
Regarding the breach of contract claims and the fraud claims, the parties both argue that 
Texas law applies because no true conflict exists between the laws of Texas and India.  The court 
agrees with the parties that no true conflict exists between the laws of Texas and the laws of 
India on breach of contract and fraud.  Under Texasโs choice-of-law rules, as no true conflict 
exists, Texas law applies to Plaintiffsโ breach of contract and fraud claims.  See Flagship Credit 
Corp., 481 F. Appโx at 910. 
B.  Negligent Misrepresentation 
As to the negligent misrepresentation claims, the court finds that a true conflict between 
Texas and Indian law exists.  Texas law requires a showing of reliance, a pecuniary loss, and the 
exercise of reasonable care or competence on the part of the speaker, whereas Indian law does 
not.  A true conflict exists, and the court must now determine the appropriate law to apply.  The 
partiesโ briefs do not appear to be discussing the same alleged misrepresentations.  Plaintiffsโ 
briefing seems primarily concerned with the alleged misrepresentations made in India by 
Defendant Dewan and Defendant Burnett, allegedly as agents of the Signal Defendants.  The 
Signal Defendantsโ brief discusses only the alleged misrepresentations they, themselves, made in 
Texas.  The Signal Defendants do not appear to take a position on what the appropriate law 
would be if Plaintiffs established an agency relationship that would confer liability on them as a 
result of the actions taken by Defendant Dewan and Defendant Burnett in India.  Plaintiffs are 
2 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 241   Filed 03/06/15   Page 3 of 3 PageID #:  7940
ordered to inform the court whether they disagree with the Signal Defendantsโ position on the 
law to apply to statements made in Texas.  If Plaintiffs do disagree, they shall set out the factual 
and legal basis for such disagreement.  Likewise, the Signal Defendants are ordered to inform the 
court if they disagree that Indian law would apply if Plaintiffs can establish that the Signal 
Defendants are liable for the alleged misrepresentations made in India by Defendant Dewan and 
Defendant Burnett.  If so, they shall set out the factual and legal basis for such disagreement. 
C.  Agency 
Plaintiffs provide a detailed comparison of Texas law regarding agency with sections of 
the Indian Contract Act of 1872, presumably because they plan to argue that Defendant Signal is 
liable for the actions taken by Defendant Dewan, Defendant Pol, and Defendant Burnett in India.  
Plaintiffs argue that no true conflict exists.  The Signal Defendants provide no choice-of-law 
analysis.  They appear to concede that an agency relationship exists, but that it is limited by the 
India Emigration Act of 1983.  Plaintiffs are ordered to inform the court if they believe that the 
Signal Defendants implication of the India Emigration Act of 1983 affects their position that no 
true conflict exists.   
III.  Conclusion 
The court finds that the partiesโ briefing on the issues of breach of contract and fraud, and 
the courtโs review, are sufficient for the court to conclude that Texas law should govern those 
claims at trial.  The parties shall have until March 13, 2015, to submit any additional choice-of-
law briefing.  Any additional briefing is limited to five pages per side.  
 
3

documents.title: Report and Recommendation on Plaintiffs' Motion to Dismiss Defendant Michael Pol (Doc. No. 98)
documents.text:
Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 216   Filed 01/27/15   Page 1 of 3 PageID #:  7615
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
BEAUMONT DIVISION 
 
BIJU MAKRUKKATTU JOSEPH, et al.  ' 
  ' 
v.    '    1:13-CV-324 
  ' 
SIGNAL INTERNATIONAL L.L.C.,    ' 
et al.  ' 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION ON PLAINTIFFSโ MOTION TO DISMISS 
DEFENDANT MICHAEL POL (DOC. NO. 98) 
 
This case is assigned to the Honorable Ron Clark, Chief United States District Judge, and 
is referred to the undersigned United States Magistrate Judge for all pretrial matters pursuant to a 
Referral Order.   (Doc. No. 4.)  Before the undersigned is the โMotion of Amended Plaintiffs to 
Dismiss  without  Prejudice  the  Claims  against  Defendant  Michael  Pol.โ    (Doc.  No.  98.)  
Plaintiffs Suresh Kakkoth, Sebastian George Pananjikal, Biju Potrayil, Pankajakshan Madhavan, 
Gijo  John,  Joy  Kallachiyil  Varkey,  Omanakuttan  Govindan  Kakkanthara,  Iju  James,  Ravi 
Rowthu,  Vasavan  Babu,  Abraham  Varghese,  Varghese  Kannampuzha  Devassy,  Paulose 
Chirackal Airookaran Joseph, and Subburaj Rengasamy (โAmended Plaintiffsโ) seek to dismiss 
their claims against Michael Pol without prejudice.   
On May 21, 2013, thirty-three Plaintiffs (โOriginal Plaintiffsโ) filed suit against multiple 
Defendants, including Michael Pol (โPolโ).  (Doc. No. 1.)   Pol filed for chapter 7 bankruptcy 
protection on June 13, 2013.  The Original Plaintiffs amended their complaint on August 1, 
2013  (Doc.  No.  19),  and  again  on  December  19,  2013.    (Doc.  No.  64.)    The  amended 
complaints  added  the  โAmended  Plaintiffs,โ  but  asserted  no  new  substantive  claims.    The 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 216   Filed 01/27/15   Page 2 of 3 PageID #:  7616
Amended Plaintiffs1 then sought dismissal of their causes of action against Pol because their 
claims  could  potentially  violate  bankruptcy  laws.    (Doc.  No.  40)  (โTo  the  extent  that  the 
Amended Plaintiffs assert new claims against Pol that could have been brought prior to the 
commencement of his Chapter 7 proceedings and were not asserted in the original Complaint, 
such claims may be voidable in light of the automatic stay.โ) (citing Sikes v. Global Marine, Inc., 
881 F.2d 176, 178โ79 (5th Cir. 1989)). 
The Plaintiffs conferred with Polโs bankruptcy counsel, and he did not oppose the relief 
sought.  The undersigned, however, denied the Amended Plaintiffsโ motion to dismiss their 
claims against Pol as moot due to the Plaintiffsโ second amended complaint.  (Doc. No. 67.)    
The Amended Plaintiffs now reassert their motion to dismiss.  (Doc. No. 98.)  There 
was no indication whether Pol consented to this reasserted motion.   In addition, no other party 
has opposed this motion and the time for doing so has passed.   
In light of Polโs bankruptcy, and given that no party has objected, the undersigned 
recommends that the โMotion of Amended Plaintiffs to Dismiss without Prejudice the Claims 
against Defendant Michael Polโ (Doc. No. 98) be GRANTED.    
Objections 
  Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 636(b)(1)(c) (Supp. IV 2011), each party to this action has the 
right to file objections to this report and recommendation.  Objections to this report must (1) be 
in writing, (2) specifically identify those findings or recommendations to which the party objects, 
(3) be served and filed within fourteen (14) days after being served with a copy of this report, 
and (4) no more than eight (8) pages in length.   See 28 U.S.C. ยง 636(b)(1)(c); FED R. CIV. P. 
72(b)(2); Local Rule CV-72(c).   A party who objects to this report is entitled to a de novo 
                                                   
1.  At this time, Paulose Chirackal Airookaran Joseph and Subburaj Rengasamy had yet to be added as 
plaintiffs and were not part of the first motion to dismiss. 
2 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 216   Filed 01/27/15   Page 3 of 3 PageID #:  7617
determination  by  the  United  States  District  Judge  of  those  proposed  findings  and 
recommendations to which a specific objection is timely made.   See 28 U.S.C. ยง 636(b)(1)(c); 
FED R. CIV. P. 72(b)(3).     
  A partyโs failure to file specific, written objections to the proposed findings of fact and 
conclusions of law contained in this report, within fourteen (14) days of being served with a copy 
of this report, bars that party from: (1) entitlement to de novo review by the United States 
District Judge of the findings of fact and conclusions of law, (see Rodriguez v. Bowen, 857 F.2d 
275, 276โ77 (5th Cir. 1988)), and (2) appellate review, except on grounds of plain error, of any 
such findings of fact and conclusions of law accepted by the United States District Judge. See 
Douglass v. United Servs. Auto. Assโn, 79 F.3d 1415, 1428โ29 (5th Cir. 1996). 
 
SIGNED this 27th day of January, 2015.
 
__________________________________________________
Zaacckk HHaawwtthhoorrnn
United States Magistrate Judge
3

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 241   Filed 03/06/15   Page 1 of 3 PageID #:  7938
** NOT FOR PRINTED PUBLICATION ** 
 
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
BEAUMONT DIVISION 
 
BIJU MAKRUKKATTU JOSEPH, et al.,  ยง 
  ยง 
 Plaintiffs,  ยง 
  ยง  CIVIL ACTION No. 1-13-CV-324 
v.  ยง 
  ยง  JUDGE RON CLARK 
SIGNAL INTERNATIONAL, LLC, et al.,  ยง 
  ยง  SJF 
 Defendants .   ยง 
 
ORDER RE: CHOICE OF LAW 
 
Defendants Signal International Texas, G.P., Signal International Texas, L.P., Signal 
International, Inc., Signal International, LLC (โSignal Defendantsโ) (Doc. # 225) and Plaintiffs 
(Doc. # 226), have filed briefs on choice of law,  in accordance with the courtโs Order 
(Doc. # 217).1  The parties provided the court with briefing regarding the law to apply to breach 
of contract, fraud, negligent misrepresentation, and agency.  The court finds that the breach of 
contract and fraud claims are governed by Texas law and orders additional briefing on negligent 
misrepresentation and agency.   
I.  Applicable Law 
A federal court sitting in diversity applies substantive law of the forum state.  Bayle v. 
Allstate Ins. Co., 615 F.3d 350, 355 (5th Cir. 2010).  The Texas Supreme Court has adopted the 
Restatement (Second) of Conflict of Laws as the proper expression of its choice-of-law rules.  
DeSantis v. Wackenhut Corp., 793 S.W.2d 670, 677 (Tex. 1990).  Under these rules, unless a 
true conflict exists between the laws of Texas and the laws of the other jurisdiction, Texas law 
                                                 
1 The other Defendants have not filed any briefing on this matter and the deadline set by 
the court for such briefing has past. 
1 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 241   Filed 03/06/15   Page 2 of 3 PageID #:  7939
applies, because it is the forum state.  Flagship Credit Corp .v. Indian Harbor Ins. Co., 481 F. 
Appโx 907, 910 (5th Cir. 2012) (citing Duncan v. Cessna Aircraft Co., 665 S.W.2d 414, 419 
(Tex.1984); Greenberg Traurig of N.Y., P.C. v. Moody, 161 S.W.3d 56, 70 (Tex.App.โHouston 
[14th Dist.] 2004, no pet.)). 
II.  Analysis 
A.  Breach of Contract and Fraud Claims 
Regarding the breach of contract claims and the fraud claims, the parties both argue that 
Texas law applies because no true conflict exists between the laws of Texas and India.  The court 
agrees with the parties that no true conflict exists between the laws of Texas and the laws of 
India on breach of contract and fraud.  Under Texasโs choice-of-law rules, as no true conflict 
exists, Texas law applies to Plaintiffsโ breach of contract and fraud claims.  See Flagship Credit 
Corp., 481 F. Appโx at 910. 
B.  Negligent Misrepresentation 
As to the negligent misrepresentation claims, the court finds that a true conflict between 
Texas and Indian law exists.  Texas law requires a showing of reliance, a pecuniary loss, and the 
exercise of reasonable care or competence on the part of the speaker, whereas Indian law does 
not.  A true conflict exists, and the court must now determine the appropriate law to apply.  The 
partiesโ briefs do not appear to be discussing the same alleged misrepresentations.  Plaintiffsโ 
briefing seems primarily concerned with the alleged misrepresentations made in India by 
Defendant Dewan and Defendant Burnett, allegedly as agents of the Signal Defendants.  The 
Signal Defendantsโ brief discusses only the alleged misrepresentations they, themselves, made in 
Texas.  The Signal Defendants do not appear to take a position on what the appropriate law 
would be if Plaintiffs established an agency relationship that would confer liability on them as a 
result of the actions taken by Defendant Dewan and Defendant Burnett in India.  Plaintiffs are 
2 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 241   Filed 03/06/15   Page 3 of 3 PageID #:  7940
ordered to inform the court whether they disagree with the Signal Defendantsโ position on the 
law to apply to statements made in Texas.  If Plaintiffs do disagree, they shall set out the factual 
and legal basis for such disagreement.  Likewise, the Signal Defendants are ordered to inform the 
court if they disagree that Indian law would apply if Plaintiffs can establish that the Signal 
Defendants are liable for the alleged misrepresentations made in India by Defendant Dewan and 
Defendant Burnett.  If so, they shall set out the factual and legal basis for such disagreement. 
C.  Agency 
Plaintiffs provide a detailed comparison of Texas law regarding agency with sections of 
the Indian Contract Act of 1872, presumably because they plan to argue that Defendant Signal is 
liable for the actions taken by Defendant Dewan, Defendant Pol, and Defendant Burnett in India.  
Plaintiffs argue that no true conflict exists.  The Signal Defendants provide no choice-of-law 
analysis.  They appear to concede that an agency relationship exists, but that it is limited by the 
India Emigration Act of 1983.  Plaintiffs are ordered to inform the court if they believe that the 
Signal Defendants implication of the India Emigration Act of 1983 affects their position that no 
true conflict exists.   
III.  Conclusion 
The court finds that the partiesโ briefing on the issues of breach of contract and fraud, and 
the courtโs review, are sufficient for the court to conclude that Texas law should govern those 
claims at trial.  The parties shall have until March 13, 2015, to submit any additional choice-of-
law briefing.  Any additional briefing is limited to five pages per side.  
 
3

documents.title: Report and Recommendation on Billy Wilks's Motion to Dismiss (Doc. No. 229)
documents.text:
Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 282   Filed 03/17/15   Page 1 of 3 PageID #:  8796
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
BEAUMONT DIVISION 
 
BIJU MAKRUKKATTU JOSEPH, et al.  ' 
  ' 
v.    '    1:13-CV-324 
  ' 
SIGNAL INTERNATIONAL L.L.C.,   ' 
et al.               ' 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION ON  
BILLY WILKSโS MOTION TO DISMISS (DOC. NO. 229) 
 
  This case is assigned to the Honorable Ron Clark, Chief United States District Judge, and 
is referred to the undersigned United States Magistrate Judge for all pretrial matters pursuant to a 
Referral Order.  (Doc. No. 4.)  Pending before the undersigned is the โMotion to Dismissโ (Doc. 
No. 229) filed by Defendant, Billy Wilks (โWilksโ).  The Plaintiffs oppose.  (Doc. No. 261.) 
  The Plaintiffs allege that Wilks is one of the โLabor Broker Defendants,โ and that this set 
of Defendants played a vital role in the alleged scheme to bring the Plaintiffs to the United States 
under the false pretense that they would receive permanent residency.  (Doc. No. 208, pp. 22โ27) 
(discussing the recruitment process).  In addition, the Plaintiffs claim that Wilks is personally 
liable for the conduct of J &M Associates of Mississippi, Inc. (โJ & Mโ) because he โhad full 
control and decision making authority over J & M such that J & M and Wilks were alter egos of 
one another.โ  (Doc. No. 208, p. 18.)   
  On February 23, 2015, Wilks filed a โMotion to Dismiss.โ  (Doc. No. 229.)  In this 
motion, Wilks seeks dismissal of the claims against him because, according to him, based on the 
โundisputed factsโ he โhad absolutely no dealings with Signal, Global, Burnet, or Dewan in the 
processing of the Plaintiffs.โ  (Id.)  Wilks also attached another motion to dismiss, which he 
claims he filed in August of 2014.  In this motion, Wilks makes the same generic assertion of 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 282   Filed 03/17/15   Page 2 of 3 PageID #:  8797
innocence.  (Id.) (โThis complaint fails to offer a bona fide claim which relief can be granted.  
None of the charges are true.โ).  This August motion, however, is not reflected on the docket.     
  After reviewing Wilksโs motion, the undersigned recommends that it be denied.  First, it is 
untimely.  The second amended scheduling order set October 17, 2014 as the deadline for 
dispositive motions.  Wilks received this order on August 4, 2014, leaving him ample time to file 
a dispositive motion.  (Doc. No. 125.)   
Setting the untimeliness of Wilksโs motion aside, his motion should be denied on the 
merits.  It appears that Wilks is moving for dismissal under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 
12(b)(6).  Accordingly, the inquiry is whether the Plaintiffs have stated a plausible claim for 
relief.  Typically, courts are not to consider extrinsic evidence and take all well-pled facts as true.  
See Lone Star Fund V (U.S.), L.P. v. Barclays Bank PLC, 594 F.3d 383, 387 (5th Cir. 2010).  
After reviewing the Plaintiffsโ complaint, the undersigned finds that they have stated a plausible 
claim against Wilks.  The Plaintiffsโ complaint offers numerous facts showing that J &M was 
involved in the recruitment process.  Moreover, there are sufficient facts that Wilks was in control 
of J & M, and therefore, it plausible that Wilks is the alter ego of J & M, and as such, personally 
liable.  Moreover, all Wilks offers to support the fact that he is not liable are blanket assertions he 
โhad no dealingsโ with the other defendants, or that โthe J & M defendants should not be in this 
suit.โ  (Doc. No. 229.)  These statements, standing alone, are insufficient to absolve Wilks of any 
wrongdoing.1  
 
                                                 
1.  Given that Wilks is proceeding pro se, his pleadings are held to less stringent standards and are to be 
construed liberally.  Haines v. Kerner, 404 U.S. 519, 520 (1972); Perez v. United States, 312 F.3d 191, 194โ95 (5th 
Cir. 2002).  Therefore, even if Wilksโs motion is construed as a motion for summary judgment, because he has 
attached no evidence to support his claim that he had no involvement in the operative facts of this case, his motion 
fails.   
2 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 282   Filed 03/17/15   Page 3 of 3 PageID #:  8798
Recommendation 
  For the reasons stated above, the undersigned recommends that Billy Wilksโs โMotion to 
Dismissโ (Doc. No. 229) be DENIED. 
Objections 
Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 636(b)(1)(c) (Supp. IV 2011), each party to this action has the right 
to file objections to this report and recommendation.  Objections to this report must (1) be in 
writing, (2) specifically identify those findings or recommendations to which the party objects, (3) 
be served and filed within fourteen (14) days after being served with a copy of this report; and (4) 
be no more than eight pages in length.  See 28 U.S.C. ยง 636(b)(1)(c); FED R. CIV. P. 72(b)(2); 
LOCAL RULE CV-72(c).  A party who objects to this report is entitled to a de novo determination 
by the United States District Judge of those proposed findings and recommendations to which a 
specific objection is timely made.  See 28 U.S.C. ยง 636(b)(1)(c); FED R. CIV. P. 72(b)(3).   
  A partyโs failure to file specific, written objections to the proposed findings of fact and 
conclusions of law contained in this report, within fourteen days of being served with a copy of this 
report, bars that party from: (1) entitlement to de novo review by the United States District Judge 
of the findings of fact and conclusions of law, see Rodriguez v. Bowen, 857 F.2d 275, 276โ77 (5th 
Cir. 1988), and (2) appellate review, except on grounds of plain error, of any such findings of fact 
and conclusions of law accepted by the United States District Judge.  See Douglass v. United 
Servs. Auto. Assโn, 79 F.3d 1415, 1428โ29 (5th Cir. 1996). 
  SIGNED this 17th day of March, 2015.
 
__________________________________________________
Zaacckk HHaawwtthhoorrnn
United States Magistrate Judge
3

documents.title: Report and Recommendations on Signal's Motion for Partial Summary Judgment (Doc. No. 161)
documents.text:
Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 219   Filed 02/04/15   Page 1 of 32 PageID #:  7621
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
BEAUMONT DIVISION 
 
BIJU MAKRUKKATTU JOSEPH, et al.  ' 
  ' 
v.    '    1:13-CV-324 
  ' 
SIGNAL INTERNATIONAL L.L.C.,   ' 
et al.  ' 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION ON SIGNALโS  
MOTION FOR PARTIAL SUMMARY JUDGMENT (DOC. NO. 161) 
 
This case is assigned to the Honorable Ron Clark, Chief United States District Judge, and 
is referred to the undersigned United States Magistrate Judge for all pretrial matters pursuant to a 
Referral Order.  (Doc. No. 4.)  Pending before the undersigned is a โMotion for Partial Summary 
Judgmentโ (Doc. No. 161) filed by Defendants Signal International, L.L.C., Signal International, 
Inc., Signal International Texas, G.P., and Signal International Texas, L.P. (collectively, โSignalโ).  
Signal seeks summary judgment on three of the Plaintiffsโ claims, arguing that some claims are 
defective as a matter of law, and that there is no genuine dispute of material fact as to others.  
After  considering  the  partiesโ  briefing  (Doc.  Nos.  161,  183,  187,  200)  and  the  applicable 
authorities, the undersigned recommends that Signalโs โMotion for Partial Summary Judgmentโ 
(Doc. No. 161) be denied. 
I. Background1 
In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, approximately 590 men, including the seventeen 
Plaintiffs in this case, were allegedly trafficked into the United States to provide labor for Signalโs 
operations.  (Doc. No.  64, pp. 2โ4.)  The Plaintiffs claim  that the Defendants  made false 
                                                   
1.  Local Rule CV-56(a) requires that a motion for summary judgment include a โStatement of Undisputed 
Facts.โ  Signalโs โStatement of Undisputed Factsโ contains both hotly contested facts, as well as legal conclusions.  
Therefore, this section contains only a brief recitation of the background of this case and should not be construed as a 
statement of facts. 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 219   Filed 02/04/15   Page 2 of 32 PageID #:  7622
promises of โpermanent work-based immigration to the United States,โ and that to take advantage 
of this promising opportunity, the Plaintiffs allegedly โplunged themselves and their families into 
debt . . . to pay mandatory recruitment, immigration processing, and travel fees . . . .โ  (Id. at p. 2.)  
After arriving at Signalโs facility in Orange, Texas, the Plaintiffs were allegedly subjected to 
serious  abuses,  threatened  with  deportation  if  they  left,  and  forced  to  live  in  substandard 
conditions.  In addition, the Plaintiffs assert that they could not leave their jobs with Signal due to 
the large debts they incurred in their homeland.  Signal denies any wrongdoing and denies that the 
Plaintiffs were subjected to forced labor, trafficking, or involuntary servitude.   
A putative class action was filed in the Eastern District of Louisiana on behalf of all the 
workers who had allegedly been trafficked to the United States to work at Signalโs facilities in 
Texas, Louisiana, and Mississippi.  (See Doc. 1, David v. Signal Intโl, L.L.C., 2:08-cv-1220 
(March 7, 2008)).  The court in David denied class certification, which caused the individual class 
members to file suit where their alleged injuries occurred.  See David v. Signal Intโl, L.L.C., No 
08-1220, 2012 WL 10759668, at *37 (E.D. La. Jan. 4, 2012).  The Plaintiffs in this case worked at 
Signalโs facility in Orange, Texas, which is within this judicial district.  
The Plaintiffs are suing Signal, as well as Malvern C. Burnett, Gulf Coast Immigration 
Law Center, L.L.C., Law Offices of Malvern C. Burnett, A.P.C, Indo-Ameri Soft, L.L.C., Kurella 
Rao, J&M Associates, Inc. of Mississippi, Billy R. Wilks, J&M Marine & Industrial, L.L.C., 
Michael Pol, Global Resources, Inc., Sachin Dewan, and Dewan Consultants Pvt. Ltd. (a/k/a 
Medtech Consultants).  The Plaintiffs allege that some or all of the Defendants violated the 
following federal statutes: (1) the Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2003; (2) 
the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act; (3) the Civil Rights Act of 1866; and (4) 
the Ku Klux Klan Act of 1871.  (Doc. No. 64, pp. 50โ68.)  In addition, the Plaintiffs assert causes 
2 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 219   Filed 02/04/15   Page 3 of 32 PageID #:  7623
of action for state law fraud, negligent misrepresentation, and breach of contract against all of the 
Defendants.  (Id.)  
II. Legal Standard 
  โSummary judgment is proper โif the movant shows that there is no genuine dispute as to 
any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.โโ  Rogers v. Bromac 
Title Servs., L.L.C., 755 F.3d 347, 350 (5th Cir. 2014) (quoting FED. R. CIV. P. 56(a)).  โA 
genuine dispute as to a material fact exists โif the evidence is such that a reasonable jury could 
return a verdict for the nonmoving party.โโ  Id. (quoting Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 
U.S. 242, 248 (1986)).  โThe party seeking summary judgment bears the initial burden of 
informing  the  court  of  the  basis  for  its  motion  and  identifying  portions  of  the  pleadings, 
depositions, answers to interrogatories, admissions on file, and affidavits, if any, which it believes 
demonstrate the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.โ  Gellhaus v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 
769 F. Supp. 2d 1071, 1074 (E.D. Tex. 2011) (Crone, J.)  This burden is not met by โmerely 
mak[ing] a conclusory statement that the other party has no evidence to prove its case.โ  Inn 
Foods, Inc. v. Mida, No. 6:06-cv-169, 2008 WL 2078965, at *2 (E.D. Tex. May 15, 2008) 
(Schneider, J.) (citing Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 328 (1986)). 
  โIf the moving party fails to meet this initial burden, the motion must be denied regardless 
of the nonmovantโs response.โ  Id. at *2 (citing Little v. Liquid Air Corp., 37 F.3d 1069, 1075 (5th 
Cir. 1994)).  โIf the movant does, however, meet this burden, the nonmovant must go beyond the 
pleadings and designate specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue for trial.โ  Little, 37 
F.3d at 1069.  The nonmovantโs โburden is not satisfied with some โmetaphysical doubt as to the 
material facts,โ by โconclusory allegations,โ by โunsubstantiated assertions,โ or by only a โscintillaโ 
of evidence.โ  Id. at 1075 (internal citations omitted).  โFactual controversies are construed in the 
3 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 219   Filed 02/04/15   Page 4 of 32 PageID #:  7624
light most favorable to the nonmovant, but only if both parties have introduced evidence showing 
that an actual controversy exists.โ  Espinoza v. Cargill Meat Solutions Corp., 622 F.3d 432, 437โ
38 (5th Cir. 2010).  
III. Analysis 
  The Plaintiffsโ second amended complaint contains six claims for relief.  (See Doc. No. 
64,  pp.  50โ68.)    Signal  moved  for  summary  judgment  on  three  claims:  violations  of  the 
Trafficking  Victims  Protection  Reauthorization  Act  of  2003  (โTVPRAโ),  violations  of  the 
Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (โRICOโ), and violations of the Ku Klux 
Klan Act of 1871 (42 U.S.C. ยง1985(3)).  (See Doc. No. 161.)  The undersigned will address 
Signalโs motion on a claim by claim basis. 
A.  First Claim: Violations of the Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2003 
 
  Congress passed the Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000 to 
โcombat trafficking in persons.โ  See Pub. L. No. 106-386, 114 Stat. 1464, 1446 (codified at 22 
U.S.C. ยง 7101 et seq.).  This act was amended in 2003 to, inter alia, create a civil remedy for 
certain violations of Chapter 77 of Title 18 of the United States Code.  See Trafficking Victims 
Protection Reauthorization Act of 2003 (โTVPRAโ), Pub. L. No. 108-193, 117 Stat. 2875, 2878 
(creating a civil remedy for violations of 18 U.S.C. ยงยง 1589, 1590, and 1591).  In their first cause 
of action, the Plaintiffs seek damages under the civil remedies provision of the TVPRA (18 U.S.C. 
ยง 1595) for โforced laborโ (18 U.S.C. ยง 1589) and โtrafficking with respect to . . . forced laborโ (18 
U.S.C. ยง 1590).2 
                                                   
2.  The Plaintiffsโ second amended complaint also alleged violations of 18 U.S.C. ยงยง 1583, 1584, and 
1592(a).  (Doc. No. 64, pp. 52โ53.)  The Plaintiffsโ response, however, is clear that they are abandoning their 
reliance on these statutes.  (See Doc. No. 183, p. 1โ2) (โPlaintiffs have therefore determined to simplify the case by 
dismissing voluntarily their claim under the TVPA to the extent it relies upon sections 1583, 1584, 1592(a) and 
1592(b).โ).  In addition, they requested leave to file a third amended complaint that deletes these claims (Doc. No. 
212), which was granted.  (Oral Order, 1/28/2015.)  The Plaintiffsโ second amended complaint will be considered as 
the operative complaint for this order, since that was the live pleading at the time of the partiesโ briefing.  
4 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 219   Filed 02/04/15   Page 5 of 32 PageID #:  7625
  Signal claims that it is entitled to summary judgment on the Plaintiffsโ trafficking claim (18 
U.S.C. ยง 1590) because (1) the TVPRA did not apply extraterritorially at the time of the alleged 
trafficking and (2) โโthat there is an absence of evidence to supportโ the case of the Plaintiffs with 
regard to the scienter required by ยง 1590 . . . .โ (Doc. No. 161, p. 20) (quoting Celotex Corp., 477 
U.S. at 325).  As for the Plaintiffsโ claims premised on violations of ยงยง 1592 and 1594, Signal 
argues that summary judgment is warranted because imposing civil liability for violations of these 
two statutes would require an impermissible retroactive application of the TVPRA.   
a.  Applying  the  TVPRA  to  the  facts  of  this  case  constitutes  a  domesticโnot 
extraterritorialโapplication of the statute 
 
Signal argues that the TVPRA did not apply extraterritorially at the time of the alleged 
trafficking, and because the Plaintiffsโ trafficking claim stems from conduct that is โsignificantly 
extraterritorial,โ their claim fails as a matter of law.  (Doc. No. 161, pp. 12โ18.)  The Plaintiffs 
do  not  dispute  that  the  TVPRA  had  no  extraterritorial  reach  prior  to  2008.   See  William 
Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008, Pub. L. No. 110-457, 
122 Stat. 5044, 5071โ72 (amending the TVPRA to confer extraterritorial jurisdiction).  Rather, 
the Plaintiffs insist that they are merely seeking a domestic application of statute, and therefore, 
whether the TVPRA can be applied extraterritorially is irrelevant.  (Doc. No. 183, pp. 9โ13.)  
The undersigned agrees with the Plaintiffs, and finds that applying the TVPRA to the facts at 
handโwhich involves trafficking workers into the United Statesโrequires only a domestic 
application of the statute.3   
                                                                                                                                                                    
 
3.  Because this case involves a domestic application of the TVPRA, the undersigned expresses no opinion 
on whether the TVPRA had any extraterritorial reach prior to 2008.  Compare Adhikari v. Dauod & Partners, 994 F. 
Supp. 2d 831, 835โ36 (S.D. Tex. 2014) (withdrawing a previous opinion and holding that the TVPRA did not apply 
extraterritorially prior to 2008).   
5 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 219   Filed 02/04/15   Page 6 of 32 PageID #:  7626
To determine whether a statute is being applied extraterritorially or domestically, courts 
are to examine the facts of the case in light of the โโfocusโ of Congressional concernโ in enacting 
the statute.  Morrison v. Natโl Austl. Bank Ltd., 561 U.S. 247, 266โ70 (2010) (โFor it is a rare 
case of prohibited extraterritorial application that lacks all contact with the territory of the United 
States.โ).  For example, in Morrison, the Supreme Court considered whether ยง10(b) of the 
Securities Exchange Act of 1934 was being applied domestically or extraterritorially.  Id.  The 
alleged misrepresentations that formed the basis of the claim were made in the United States and 
were about an American company, but the securities that were affected were only traded on a 
foreign stock exchange.  Id. at 251โ53.  The Supreme Court found that the focus of ยง10(b) was 
on โtransactions in securities listed on domestic exchanges, and domestic transactions in other 
securities,โ as opposed to where the misrepresentations occurred.  Id. at 267.  Therefore, because 
the securities were only traded on a foreign exchange, as opposed to a domestic exchange, 
imposing liability would require an extraterritorial application of the statute. 
After reviewing the plain language of the TVPRA, as well as the legislative history, the 
undersigned finds that what is critical under the TVPRA is โwhere the forced labor occurred and to 
where to victims were trafficked, and not from where the victims were trafficked . . . .โ  Tanedo v. 
E. Baton Rouge Parish Sch. Bd., No. SA CV 10-01172, 2012 WL 5378742, at * 6 (C.D. Cal. Aug. 
27, 2012) (emphasis added) (reaching this conclusion based on a comparison to the facts of 
Morrison).  For example, the Congressional findings supporting the passage of the Victims of 
Trafficking  and  Violence  Protection  Act  of  2000โwhich  are  codified  at  22  U.S.C. 
ยง 7101(b)โrecognize  that  trafficking  victims  are  โtrafficked  within  or  across  international 
borders,โ and that โtraffickers often transport victims from their home communities to unfamiliar 
destinations, including foreign countries.โ  22 U.S.C. ยง 7101(b)(1), (5); see also Tanedo, 2012 
6 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 219   Filed 02/04/15   Page 7 of 32 PageID #:  7627
WL 5378742, at *6 (citing H.R. Conf. Rep. No. 106-939, at 1 (2000)).  Here, it is undisputed that 
the Plaintiffs were eventually brought to the United States.  Accordingly, imposing liability under 
ยง 1590 requires only a domestic application of the statute.  (See Doc. No. 2077, David v. Signal 
Intโl, L.L.C., 2:08-cv-1220 (E.D. La. Jan. 6, 2015) (finding that the plaintiffsโ claims under the 
TVPRA are not extraterritorial)).   
Signal argues that the undersigned should follow Adhikari v. Dauod & Partners, 994 F. 
Supp. 2d 831 (S.D. Tex. 2014), which dismissed a trafficking claim on the grounds that the 
TVPRA did not apply extraterritorially prior to 2008.  (See Doc. No. 161, pp. 13โ17); see 
Adhikari, 994 F. Supp. 2d at 835โ37.  Signal, however, overlooks a critical distinctionโthe 
workers in Adhikari were not trafficked to the United Statesโthey were trafficked from Nepal to 
Iraq.4  Adhikari, 994 F. Supp. 2d at 835โ37; see also John Roe I v. Bridgestone Corp., 492 F. Supp. 
2d 998, 990, 999โ1002 (S.D. Ind. 2007) (holding that the TVPRA did not apply where the alleged 
involuntary servitude occurred solely in Liberia).  Thus, Adhikari is not on point.  
  Accordingly, the undersigned agrees with the Plaintiffs and finds the that transporting or 
recruiting of workers into the United States is a domesticโnot extraterritorialโapplication of the 
TVPRA.  The fact that the Plaintiffs are foreign or some of the acts may have occurred abroad 
does not change the domestic character of the Plaintiffsโ claims. 
b.  The Plaintiffs have put forth enough evidence to create a genuine dispute of 
material fact as to whether Signal is liable for trafficking 
 
  Signal next argues that summary judgment is warranted because โthe Plaintiffs have no 
evidence to prove [] that Signal always subjectively intended to convert the recruited individuals 
                                                   
4.  Some of the workers were told that their ultimate destination would be an American military installation

Section 1590 states: โwhoever knowingly recruits, harbors, transports, provides, or obtains

(creating a civil remedy for violations of ยง 1590).  By its terms, ยง 1590 requires recruiting or 
transporting a person with the knowledge that it is for, amongst other things, forced labor.  
โKnowinglyโ means having the factual knowledge.  See United States v. Ho, 311 F.3d 589, 605

5.  Perhaps the undersignedโs confusion stems from Signalโs extensive discussion of Morrissette v. United

270โ74.  Therefore, if the jury believed that he thought the property had been abandoned, he did not โknowinglyโ

Signal next argues that to the extent that the Plaintiffsโ trafficking claim is premised on the

working for Signal, this was not actionable under the TVPRA until 2008.  (Doc. No. 161, pp. 27โ
31.)  โSerious harmโ was not defined in the original statute.  The 2008 amendments added a 
definition:  
The  term  โserious  harmโ  means  any  harm,  whether  physical  or  nonphysical, 
including psychological, financial, or reputational harm, that is sufficiently serious, 
under all the surrounding circumstances, to compel a reasonable person of the same 
background and in the same circumstances to perform or to continue performing 
labor or services in order to avoid incurring that harm.   
 
See William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008, Pub. L. No. 
110-457, 122 Stat. 5044, 5069.  Signal argues that because financial harm was added to the 
TVPRA in 2008, and โCongress does not legislate unnecessarily,โ financial harm could not have 
been part of the statute prior to 2008.  (Doc. No. 161, pp. 28โ29.)  Therefore, Signal asserts that 
imposing liability based on financial coercion would be an impermissible retroactive application

alleged trafficking, to encompass their claim of financial coercion.  (Doc. No. 183, pp. 13โ20.)   
  The undersigned is not persuaded by Signalโs argument.  First, while financial coercion 
may be a part of the Plaintiffsโ claim, it is not their only basis for imposing liability under the 
TVPRA.  As discussed above, there appears to be other alleged actions taken by Signal that meet 
the definition of forced labor under the TVPRA.  Second, the plain language of the statute 
demonstrates that it encompasses more than just threats of physical harm.  Forced labor was 
defined at the relevant time as โthreats of serious harm . . . or physical restraint.โ  As the court in 
Tanedo noted: โThat ยง 1589 distinguishes between serious harm and physical restraint indicates

country.โโ  Id. (quoting H.R. Conf. Rep. No. 106-939, at 101 (2000)).  In addition, while not 
directly addressing a claim of financial coercion, the Fifth Circuit found that, prior to 2008,

a.  The Plaintiffs have alleged a distinct RICO person and RICO enterprise 
 Signal argues that the Plaintiffsโ RICO claim is โstructurally defectiveโ because the 
Plaintiffs โallege both that Signal is a RICO โpersonโ and that Signal was a โmemberโ of all RICO 
Enterprises alleged in the Second Claim for Relief . . . .โ  (Id. at p. 31โ32.)  Signalโs argument 
misconstrues the Plaintiffsโ complaint, as well as misapplies the law on the person/enterprise 
distinction under RICO.  
โRICO claims under ยง 1962 require: โ(1) a person who engages in (2) a pattern of 
racketeering activity, (3) connected to the acquisition, establishment, conduct, or control of an 
enterprise.โ  Bradley v. Phillips Petroleum Co., 527 F. Supp. 2d 625, 645 (S.D. Tex. 2007) 
14 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 219   Filed 02/04/15   Page 15 of 32 PageID #:  7635
(quoting In re Burzynski, 989 F.2d 733, 741โ42 (5th Cir. 1993)) (emphasis in original).  โTo 
establish liability under ยง 1962(c) one must allege and prove the existence of two distinct entities: 
(1) a โpersonโ; and (2) an โenterpriseโ that is not simply the same โpersonโ referred to by a different 
name.โ  Cedric Kushner Promotions, Ltd. v. King, 533 U.S. 158, 161 (2001).  RICO defines a 
โpersonโ as โany individual or entity capable of holding a legal or beneficial interest in property.โ  
18 U.S.C. ยง1961(3).  Signal does not dispute that it can be a RICO person.  See St. Paul Mercury 
Ins. Co. v. Williamson, 224 F.3d 425, 447 (5th Cir. 2000) (โ[A] corporation obviously qualifies as 
a โpersonโ under RICO and may be subject to RICO liability.โ) (quoting Haroco, Inc. v. Am. Natโl 
Bank & Trust Co., 747 F.2d 384, 401 (7th Cir. 1984)).   
โAn enterprise under RICO can include the usual legal entities such as partnerships and 
corporations, but it also can include โany union or group of individuals associated in fact although 
not a legal entity . . . .โโ  Bradley, 527 F. Supp. 2d at 651 (quoting Manax v. McNamara, 842 F.2d 
808,  811  (5th  Cir.  1988)).    The  Supreme  Court  has  indicated  that  โenterpriseโ  should  be 
interpreted broadly.  See Boyle v. United States, 556 U.S. 938, 943โ45 (2009) (noting that the 
โvery concept of an association in fact is expansiveโ).  Here, the Plaintiffs argue that there are two 
association in fact type enterprises, both of which Signal is a member.  (Doc. No. 183, pp. 26โ27.)  
To establish such an enterprise, the Plaintiffs must show evidence of โan ongoing organization, 
formal or informal, and evidence that the various associates function as a continuing unit.โ  
Boyle, 556 U.S. at 944. 
In addition, for claims under ยง 1962(c), courts also require that the RICO person and RICO 
enterprise be distinct.  St. Paul Mercury Ins., 224 F.3d at 447  (โ[S]ubsection (c) requires that the 
RICO person be distinct from the RICO enterprise.โ).  This is where Signal argues that the 
Plaintiffsโ claim is defective.  Signal insists that because โthe Complaint alleges both that Signal 
15 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 219   Filed 02/04/15   Page 16 of 32 PageID #:  7636
is a RICO โpersonโ and that Signal was a โmemberโ of all RICO enterprises,โ the Plaintiffs have 
failed to allege an enterprise that is separate and distinct from Signal itself.  (Doc. No. 161, p. 31.)   
Signalโs argument is misplaced.  First, Signal is simply incorrect when it asserts that the 
Plaintiffs are alleging that โSignal enterprised with itself.โ  (Doc. No. 187, p. 5.)  The Plaintiffs 
have alleged that Signal is a member of an enterprise; they have not alleged that the entire 
enterprise consists only of Signal and its officers, directors, or employees.  Compare Atkinson v. 
Anadarko Bank & Trust Co., 808 F.2d 438, 440 (5th Cir. 1987) (holding that โAnadarko Bank, 
Anadarko Bankshares, and [] three employeesโ were not an association in fact enterprise separate 
and distinct from Andarko Bank because there was no evidence that these entities โwere associated 
in any manner apart from the activities of the bankโ). 
Second, Signal misconstrues the relevant case law.  The cases cited by Signal do not stand 
for the proposition that the Plaintiffsโ RICO claim is defective as a matter of law merely because a 
corporation is named as a person and a part of a RICO enterprise.  Rather, these cases hold that the 
distinctiveness element was not satisfied based on the facts.  For example, in  Bradley, the 
plaintiffs alleged that the enterprise consisted of a group of companies.  Bradley, 527 F. Supp. 2d 
at 651.  The court found that there was nothing in the plaintiffsโ complaint โto suggest that the 
enterprise existed for any reason other than to commit the alleged predicate acts.โ  Id.  Moreover, 
the court found that โeven if [the plaintiffs] had adequately pled an enterprise, they have failed to 
plead that any Defendants were โemployed by or associated with [the] enterpriseโ as required 
under  ยง 1962(c).โ    Id.  at  651โ52.   Signal  has  not  pointed  to  anything  in  the  record  that 
demonstrates, as a matter of fact, that the alleged enterprises are not distinct from the various 
members.  Accordingly, Signal has not met its burden for summary judgment.   
16 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 219   Filed 02/04/15   Page 17 of 32 PageID #:  7637
Moreover, Bradley did not hold that a corporation could notโas a matter of lawโbe 
named as part of an enterprise.  What Signal appears to be alluding to is a line of cases holding 
that when a corporation is named as a RICO person, and that same corporation is named as the 
enterprise, the distinctiveness requirement may not be satisfied.  See Atkinson, 808 F.2d at 440; 
see also Heden v. Hill, 937 F. Supp. 1230, 1242 (S.D. Tex. 1996) (โWhen the alleged Section 
1962(c) violator is a legal entity, such as a corporation, this required separation is not established 
by  merely  showing  that  the  corporation,  through  its  employees,  officers,  and/or  directors, 
committed a pattern of predicate acts in the conduct of its own business.โ).  As the Second Circuit 
noted, alleging a corporation as a member of an enterprise โdoes not foreclose the possibility of a 
corporate entity being held liable as a defendant under Section 1962(c) where it associates with 
others to form an enterprise that is sufficiently distinct from itself.โ  See Riverwoods Chappaqua 
Corp. v. Marine Midland Bank, N.A., 30 F. 3d 339, 344 (2d Cir. 1994).  In other words, groups of 
corporations  can  form  an  association  in  fact  type  enterprise,  but  a  party  cannot  avoid  the 
distinctiveness requirement by โalleging a RICO enterprise that consists merely of a corporation 
defendant associated with its own employees or agents carrying on the regular affairs of the 
defendants.โ  Isystems v. Spark Networks, Ltd., No. 10-10905, 2012 WL 3101672, at *5 (5th Cir. 
March 21, 2012) (per curiam) (quoting Khurana v. Innovative Health Care Sys., 130 F.3d 143, 
155) (5th Cir. 1997)); see also Atlas Pile Driving Co. v. DiCon Fin. Co., 886 F.2d 986, 995 (8th 
Cir.  1989)  (upholding  allegations  of  an  enterprise  that  consisted  of  multiple  corporations).  
Because the Plaintiffs have alleged a larger enterprise than just Signal, the Plaintiffsโ claim is not 
structurally defective as a matter of law.7  (See also Doc. No. 2115, David v. Signal Intโl, L.L.C.,

โto allege association-in-fact enterprises that include (and in many cases consist only of) corporations or other legal

so broadly).  While these commentators raise interesting points, until the Supreme Court revisits Boyle, which

issues that these commentators were discussing.  Rather, Signalโs argument is based on the faulty premise that the

(8th ed. 2004).  The undersigned understands this to mean that to the extent that the Plaintiffs have plead a civil RICO
