documents.title: Memorandum and Order on the Parties' Motions to Exclude Expert Testimony
documents.text:
Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 1 of 38 PageID #:  7655
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
BEAUMONT DIVISION 
 
BIJU MAKRUKKATTU JOSEPH, et al.  ' 
  ' 
v.    '    1:13-CV-324 
  ' 
SIGNAL INTERNATIONAL L.L.C.,   ' 
et al.  ' 
 
MEMORANDUM AND ORDER ON THE PARTIESโ  
MOTIONS TO EXCLUDE EXPERT TESTIMONY 
 
This case is assigned to the Honorable Ron Clark, Chief United States District Judge, and 
is referred to the undersigned United States Magistrate Judge for pretrial proceedings pursuant to 
a referral order entered on May 22, 2013.  (Doc. No. 4.)  Pending before the undersigned are ten 
motions to exclude and/or limit expert testimony.  The Plaintiffs moved to exclude the following 
experts: Ronald J. McAlear, Virginia Miles, Dr. Kevin Fox Gotham, Donald H. Strobel, Enrique 
Gonzalez, and Dr. Louise Shelley.  (Doc. Nos.  150, 151, 152, 154, 155, 156.)  Defendants 
Signal International, L.L.C., Signal International, Inc., Signal International Texas, G.P., Signal 
International Texas, L.P. (collectively, โSignalโ) moved to exclude the Plaintiffsโ experts Amy 
Mowl and Florence Burke.  (Doc. Nos. 157, 158.)  Defendants Malvern C. Burnett, the Law 
Offices  of  Malvern  Burnett,  A.P.C.,  and  the  Gulf  Coast  Immigration  Law  Center,  L.L.C. 
(collectively, โBurnettโ) moved to exclude Signalโs expert, Enrique Gonzalez.  (Doc. No. 153.)  
Defendants Sachin Dewan and Dewan Consultants Pvt. Ltd. (collectively, โDewanโ) moved to 
exclude Signalโs expert, Dr. Louise Shelley.  (Doc. No. 159.)  Because the motions all relate to 
the same operative facts, apply the same law, and at times relate to one another, the undersigned 
will address all the pending motions in one order. 
 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 2 of 38 PageID #:  7656
 
I.  BACKGROUND 
 
In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, approximately 590 men, including the seventeen 
Plaintiffs in this case, were allegedly trafficked into the United States to provide labor for 
Signalโs operations.  (Doc. No. 64, pp. 2โ4.)  The Plaintiffs claim that the Defendants made false 
promises  of  โpermanent  work-based  immigration  to  the  United  States,โ  and  that  to  take 
advantage of this promising opportunity, the Plaintiffs allegedly โplunged themselves and their 
families into debt . . . to pay mandatory recruitment, immigration processing, and travel fees . . 
. .โ  (Id. at p. 2.)  After arriving at Signalโs facility in Orange, Texas, the Plaintiffs were allegedly 
subjected  to  serious  abuses,  threatened  with  deportation  if  they  left,  and  forced  to  live  in 
substandard conditions.  In addition, the Plaintiffs assert that they could not leave their jobs with 
Signal due to the large debts they incurred in their homeland.  Signal denies any wrongdoing and 
denies that the Plaintiffs were subjected to forced labor, trafficking, or involuntary servitude.   
A putative class action was filed in the Eastern District of Louisiana on behalf of all the 
workers who had allegedly been trafficked to the United States to work at Signalโs facilities in 
Texas, Louisiana, and Mississippi.  (See Doc. 1, David v. Signal Intโl, L.L.C., 2:08-cv-1220 
(March 7, 2008)).  The court in David denied class certification, which caused the individual 
class members to file suit where their alleged injuries occurred.  See David v. Signal Intโl, 
L.L.C., No 08-1220, 2012 WL 10759668, at *37 (E.D. La. Jan. 4, 2012).  The Plaintiffs in this 
case worked at Signalโs facility in Orange, Texas, which is within this judicial district.  
The Plaintiffs allege that some or all of the Defendants violated the following federal 
statutes: (1) the Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2003; (2) the Racketeer 
Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act; (3) the Civil Rights Act of 1866; and (4) the Ku Klux 
Klan Act of 1871.  (Doc. No. 64, pp. 50โ68.)  In addition, the Plaintiffs assert causes of action 
2 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 3 of 38 PageID #:  7657
for  state  law  fraud,  negligent  misrepresentation,  and  breach  of  contract  against  all  of  the 
Defendants.  (Id.)  
II. LEGAL STANDARD 
 
The admission or exclusion of expert testimony is a matter within the discretion of the 
district court.  Kuhmo Tire Co. v. Carmichael, 526 U.S. 137, 152 (1999); Huss v. Gayden, 571 
F.3d 442, 452 (5th Cir. 2009).  Federal Rule of Evidence 702 provides: 
If scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the trier of fact 
to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness qualified as 
an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education, may testify 
thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise, if (1) the testimony is based upon 
sufficient facts or data, (2) the testimony is the product of reliable principles and 
methods, and (3) the witness has applied the principles and methods reliably to 
the facts of the case. 
 
FED. R. EVID. 702; accord Kuhmo Tire Co., 526 U.S. at 152; Daubert v. Merrel Dow Pharms., 
Inc., 509 U.S. 579, 588 (1993).  The proponent of the proffered expert testimony โhas the burden 
of establishing, by a preponderance of the evidence, that the pertinent admissibility requirements 
are met.โ  United States v. Fullwood, 342 F.3d 409, 412 (5th Cir. 2003) (citing FED. R. EVID. 
104(a)).      
The  district  court  is  to  consider  several  criteria  in  determining  whether  an  expertโs 
opinion is admissible.  First, whether the proffered expert is qualified to testify because of his 
knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education.  United States v. Cooks, 589 F.3d 173, 179 
(5th Cir. 2009) (citing FED. R. EVID. 702); Wilson v. Woods, 163 F.3d 935, 937 (5th Cir. 1999).  
โ[T]o qualify as an expert, โthe witness must have such knowledge or experience in [his] field or 
calling as to make it appear that his opinion or inference will probably aid the trier in his search 
for truth.โโ  United States v. Hicks, 389 F.3d 514, 524 (5th Cir. 2004) (quoting United States v. 
Bourgeois, 950 F.2d 980, 987 (5th Cir. 1992)) (internal quotations omitted).   
3 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 4 of 38 PageID #:  7658
  Next, whether the proffered expertโs testimony is reliable.  See Kuhmo Tire Co., 526 U.S. 
at  152.    The  court  possesses  considerable  flexibility  in  assessing  the  reliability  of  expert 
testimony.  Id. at 141; Stolt Achievement, Ltd. v. Dredge B. E. Lindholm, 447 F.3d 360, 366 (5th 
Cir. 2006).  While the Daubert factors are the most common benchmark, the court should 
consider all relevant factors, and is not required to analyze the Daubert factors in every case.  
Stolt Achievement, Ltd, 447 F.3d at 366 (citing Kuhmo Tire Co., 526 U.S. at 149).  The 
overarching goal โis to make certain that an expert . . . employs in the courtroom the same level 
of intellectual rigor that characterizes the practice of an expert in the relevant field.โ  Kuhmo 
Tire Co., 526 U.S. at 152.   
  โThe [c]ourtโs role is that of a gatekeeper only, limited to determining admissibility, not 
credibility of the evidence.โ  Knox v. Ferrer, No. 5:07-CV-6, 2008 WL 4411326, at *2 (S.D. 
Miss. Sept. 22, 2008) (citing Pipitone v. Biomatrix, Inc., 288 F.3d 239, 244 (5th Cir. 2002)).  
This  role requires a  court  to  make โa preliminary assessment of whether the reasoning or 
methodology underlying the testimony is scientifically valid and of whether that reasoning or 
methodology properly can be applied to the facts in issue.โ  Daubert, 509 U.S. at 592โ93.  The 
court should approach this task โwith proper deference to the juryโs role as the arbiter of disputes 
between conflicting opinions.โ United States v. 14.38 Acres of Land, 80 F.3d 1074, 1077 (5th 
Cir. 1996) (quoting Viterbo v. Dow Chem Co., 826 F.2d 420, 422 (5th Cir. 1987)) (internal 
quotations omitted).  
  The courtโs assessment of admissibility is not intended to replace the adversarial system, 
which should highlight weak evidence.  Primrose Operating Co. v. Natโl Am. Ins. Co., 382 F.3d 
546, 562 (5th Cir. 2004).  โVigorous cross-examination, presentation of contrary evidence, and 
careful instruction on the burden of proof are the traditional and appropriate means of attacking 
4 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 5 of 38 PageID #:  7659
shaky but admissible evidence.โ  Daubert, 509 U.S. at 596.  โThe Daubert analysis should not 
supplant trial on the merits.โ  Mathis v. Exxon Corp., 302 F.3d 448, 461 (5th Cir. 2002) (citing 
Pipitone, 288 F.3d at 250).      
  Finally, the court must determine that the proffered expert testimony is relevant.  See 
FED. R. EVID. 702 (stating that expert testimony is admissible only if it โwill assist the trier of 
fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issueโ).  Evidence is relevant if it โhas 
any tendency to make the existence of any fact that is of consequence to the determination of the 
action more probable or less probable than it would be without the evidence.โ  FED. R. EVID. 
401.     
III. ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Plaintiffsโ โMotion to Exclude Ron J. McAlear as Expertโ (Doc. No. 150) 
 
Signal  retained  Ronald  J.  McAlear  (โMcAlearโ)  โfor  the  purposes  of  providing 
information and guidance on Shipyard normal and customary practices . . . .โ  (Doc. No. 150, Ex. 
C, p. 1.)  McAlear is an engineer, holds a masterโs degree from the Massachusetts Institute of 
Technology, and has spent his career working in all facets of the shipbuilding industry, including 
at the management level.  (Id. at pp. 1โ2.)  Though difficult to discern precisely what McAlearโs 
opinions are, it appears that he concludes that Signal โapplies the normal and customary industry 
practicesโ in several areas, including: safety, quality, the environment, the use of I.D. badges, 
and the issuance of personal protective equipment.  (Id. at pp. 28โ29.)   
The Plaintiffs seek to exclude McAlear as an expert on the grounds that: (1) he is not 
qualified to testify as an expert on safety; (2) his opinions are irrelevant; (3) his opinions are not 
based on sufficient or reliable facts or data; and (4) his methodology is flawed.  (Doc. No. 150, 
pp. 11โ14.)  In addition, should the undersigned not completely exclude McAlear, the Plaintiffs 
5 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 6 of 38 PageID #:  7660
seek to limit his opinions to those contained in the report that was served on July 29, 2014โthe 
โTexas Reportโโarguing that a later served report was untimely.  (Id. at pp. 10โ11.)  
a.  Timeliness of the David Report 
  As an initial matter, the Plaintiffs seek to limit McAlearโs opinions to those contained in 
the Texas Report.  (Id.)  The Plaintiffs argue that McAlear drafted a more robust report for use in 
a parallel caseโthe โDavid Reportโโafter โrecognizing that the Texas Report was woefully 
inadequate.โ  (Id. at p. 4.)  While the Texas Report was timely, the David Report was served in 
this case on August 27, 2014, weeks after the deadline for disclosing experts passed.  (See Doc. 
No. 122) (setting July 29, 2014 as the deadline for defendants to serve expert reports).   
  โRule 26(a) requires the expertโs initial report to include โa complete statement of all 
opinions the witness will express and the basis and reasons for them.โโ  Culter v. Louisville 
Ladder, Inc., No. 4:10-4684, 2012 WL 2994271, at *5 (S.D. Tex. July 20, 2012) (quoting FED. R. 
CIV. P. 26(a)(2)(B)(i)) (emphasis in original).  In addition, the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 
impose a duty to supplement expert reports.  See FED. R. CIV. P. 26(a)(2)(E); 26(e).  Courts, 
however, have struck so-called โsupplementalโ reports when they were offered not because of 
newly learned information or to correct an error in the initial report, as is contemplated by the 
Rules, but  rather were  merely  an attempt to  bolster the original  report.  Culter, 2012 WL 
2994271 at *5; see also Gallagher v. S. Source Packaging, L.L.C., 568 F. Supp. 2d 624, 631 
(E.D.N.C. 2008) (โCourts distinguish โtrue supplementationโ (e.g. correcting inadvertent errors 
or omissions) from gamesmanship, and have therefore repeatedly rejected attempts to avert 
summary judgment by โsupplementingโ an expert report with a โnew and improvedโ expert 
report.โ).  Such a decision lies within the discretion of the court.  See Reliance Ins. Co. v. La. 
6 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 7 of 38 PageID #:  7661
Land & Exploration Co., 110 F.3d 253, 257โ58 (5th Cir. 1997) (finding that the district court did 
not abuse its discretion in refusing to allow a late filed supplemental report). 
  Here, the David Report cannot fairly be classified as merely a supplement to the Texas 
Report.  Signal points to no newly learned information or errors that McAlear sought to correct.  
Rather, Signal asserts that the David Report provides โgreater explanation and support for Mr. 
McAlearโs conclusionsโโthis is the antithesis of a supplemental report.  (Doc. No. 173, p. 9.)  
The Plaintiffs, however, fail to identify how they have been prejudiced.  See Geiserman v. 
MacDonald, 893 F.2d 787, 791 (5th Cir. 1990) (affirming the district courtโs enforcement of a 
scheduling order that resulted in a party not being able to present expert testimony, and noting 
that one of the factors was the โpotential prejudice in allowingโ the late testimony).  The David 
Report was served well in advance of McAlearโs deposition, and the Plaintiffs do not assert that 
their preparation was hindered.  Furthermore, the Plaintiffs have not claimed that the late report 
required them to retain a new expert, or that it was merely offered as an attempt to avoid 
summary judgment.  See Reliance Ins. Co., 110 F.3d at 257 (noting that if a late supplemental 
report were allowed, the defendants could potentially be required to seek a rebuttal witness and a 
delay would have been inevitable); Culter, 2012 WL 2994271 at *5.  
The  undersigned  does  not  condone  the  serving  of  a  late  expert  reportโparticularly 
without seeking leave to do so.  However, given the logistical complexities of having multiple 
cases proceeding at the same time in two districts, and the fact that the Plaintiffs were unable to 
show any prejudice, the David Report will be considered as the operative expert report for this 
case.    
 
 
7 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 8 of 38 PageID #:  7662
b.  Scope of McAlearโs opinions 
Before discussing the Plaintiffsโ specific arguments, it necessary to clarify the scope 
McAlearโs opinions.  The Plaintiffs characterize McAlear as โan expert on safety practices,โ and 
most of their arguments are aimed at excluding McAlear as a safety expert.  (Doc. No. 150, pp. 
11โ12.)  Signal concedes that he is not an expert on safety, and asserts that he is merely opining 
about whether โa company operates customarily in the industry relative to safety.โ  (Doc. No. 
173, pp. 5โ6.)   Signal  also  identifies  other  general  areas, aside from safety practices,  that 
McAlear discusses.  (Id. at p. 2โ3.)   
McAlear, however, at times opines that Signalโs facilities were in fact safe.  For example, 
he states, โSignal has operated one of the safest shipyards in the Industryโ and that Signalโs 
โsafety record is evident when you compare the historical safety performance ratings from 2003 
to 2013.โ  (Doc. No. 150, Ex. C, p. 25.)  McAlear goes so far as to call Signalโs safety record 
โexemplary.โ  (Id.)  Such opinions go beyond merely  discussing what is customary in the 
industry.   
The  undersigned  finds  that  McAlearโs  opinions  on  safety  are  inadmissible  for  two 
reasons.  First, McAlear admits that he is โnot an expert in safety.โ  (Doc. No. 150, Ex. B, 
131:12.)  Therefore, he is not qualified to render such opinions.  Second, he has not examined 
sufficient information nor applied a reliable or meaningful principle to reach these particular 
conclusions.  Rendering an opinion that Signalโs safety record is โexemplaryโ would require 
considering and balancing Signalโs safety record against that of other companies or against 
identifiable industry standards.  McAlear undertook no such analysis.  Conversely, to opine 
generally that Signalโs practices are consistent with industry customs only requires being familiar 
with the industry and being familiar with Signalโs practices.  
8 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 9 of 38 PageID #:  7663
  Accordingly, McAlearโs opinions are limited to those relating to customary practices 
within the marine fabrication industry, and he may not opine as to whether Signalโs facilities 
were in fact safe. 
c.  McAlear is qualified to testify about industry customs 
The Plaintiffs argue that McAlearโs report should be excluded because he admitted that 
he is not an expert on safety, and therefore, not qualified to testify as an expert.  (Doc. No. 150, 
p. 12.)  However, as discussed above, the Plaintiffsโ characterization of McAlearโs opinions is 
too narrow.  He is not just opining on whether Signal is a safe company or about its safety 
record.  Rather, he discusses general industry customs and Signalโs practices measured against 
those customs.  Given McAlearโs โ[o]ver 40 years of experience in all aspects of the Marine 
Industry,โ  including  experience  in  managing  and  running  shipyards,  his  practical  work 
experience qualifies him as an expert about general practices in the industry.  (Doc. No. 150, Ex. 
C, App. A); see also Martin v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., No. 2:10-cv-268, 201l WL 6399690, at  *1 
(S.D. Miss. Dec. 20, 2011) (finding that an expertโs twenty-four  years of work experience 
qualified him to testify as an expert); Satcher v. Honda Motor Co., 52 F.3d 1311, 1317โ18 (5th 
Cir. 1995) (holding that the district court did not err in finding an expert qualified to testify based 
on his experience). 
d.  McAlearโs opinions are relevant 
The Plaintiffs claim that McAlearโs report should be struck because โ[g]eneral standards 
and practices in the industry and Signalโs shipyard safety practices are not relevant toโ any of 
their claims.  (Doc. No. 150, p. 11.)  In response, Signal asserts that due to the Plaintiffsโ factual 
allegations about the use of I.D. badges and unsafe working conditions, McAlearโs opinions 
about general industry practices are relevant.  (Doc. No. 173, pp. 2โ5.)  Signal is correctโthe 
9 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 10 of 38 PageID #:  7664
Plaintiffsโ complaint makes numerous references to the conditions of employment imposed by 
Signal.  For example, the Plaintiffsโ complaint discusses the testing and re-testing by Signal, the 
fact that Signal charged the Plaintiffs for job-related tool kits, the use of I.D. badges, and general 
working conditions.  (See Doc. No. 64, pp. 38โ50.)  
Expert  testimony  is  admissible  if  it  will  โhelp  the  trier  of  fact  to  understand  the 
evidence . . . .โ    See   F ED.  R.  CIV.  702.   To  the  extent  that  the  Plaintiffs  criticize  certain 
conditions of their employment and complain that they were working in substandard conditions, 
expert testimony claiming that these are customary practices is relevant.  Moreover, a potential 
juror is unlikely to be familiar with customary shipyard practices, and as such, expert testimony 
will assist the jury on this topic.  The Plaintiffs, however, claim that the issue is not whether 
Signal operates its facility in a way that is consistent with industry customs, but rather, whether 
the Plaintiffs were treated differently than other similarly situated non-Indian workers employed 
by Signal.  (Doc. No. 189, p. 2) (โ[T]he practices of the industry at large, with respect to all 
employees, are irrelevant to the issue of Signalโs treatment of the Plaintiffs relative to other 
Signal employees.โ).  While the disparate treatment of the Plaintiffs may be the ultimate issue as 
to the Plaintiffsโ ยง 1981 claim, to the extent that the Plaintiffs raise certain issues about Signalโs 
practices, it would be helpful to a jury (albeit marginally) to learn about general practices in the 
industry.  Accordingly, while McAlearโs testimony may not be a perfect fit to the ultimate issue 
in this case, it is relevant enough to be admissible.  See U.S. v. Tucker, 345 F.3d 320, 327 (5th 
Cir. 2003) (noting that the relevance inquiry centers on โwhether expert testimony proffered in 
the case is sufficiently tied to the facts of the case that it will aid the jury in resolving a factual 
disputeโ) (quoting Daubert, 509 U.S. at 591).  
 
10 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 11 of 38 PageID #:  7665
e.  McAlearโs opinions are based sufficient facts and data 
Next, the Plaintiffs contend that McAlearโs report should be struck because he based his 
opinions on documents found on Signalโs website.  (Doc. No. 150, p. 12โ13.)  Stated another 
way, McAlear did not consider a sufficient amount of information from a reliable source.  This 
type of challenge goes to the weight of his testimony, not its admissibility.  See 14.38 Acres of 
Land, 80 F.3d at 1077 (โAs a general rule, questions relating to the bases and sources of an 
expertโs opinion affect the weight to be assigned that opinion rather than its admissibility and 
should be left for the juryโs consideration.โ).  Moreover, a review of Appendix B to the David 
Report  illustrates  that  McAlear  reviewed  materials  beyond  just  those  available  on  Signalโs 
website.  (Doc. No. 150, Ex. C, App. B.)  In fact, in their argument about all the differences 
between the Texas Report and the David Report, the Plaintiffs highlight all the information that 
McAlear  considered.    (Doc.  No.  150,  pp.  4โ6)  (noting  that  McAlear  considered  ISO 
certifications,  deposition  excerpts,  and  even  conducted  an  โinformal  surveyโ  on  tools  and 
protective  gear).    Accordingly,  the  undersigned  finds  that  McAlear  has  reviewed  enough 
information to opine on whether Signalโs practices meet industry norms.  To the extent that the 
Plaintiffs  wish  to  challenge  the  bases  for  McAlearโs  opinions,  they  can  do  so  on  cross-
examination. 
f.  McAlearโs opinions are the product of reliable principles and/or methods 
The Plaintiffs state that McAlear has met none of the Daubert factors.  (Doc. No. 150, pp. 
13โ14.)  The relevant inquiry, however, is not whether any or all of the Daubert factors are met, 
but rather, whether there is any reasonable criteria on which the expert based his opinion.  See 
Stolt Achievement, Ltd., 447 F.3d at 366; see also Huck v. City of Beaumont, 147 F. Supp. 2d 
565, 568 (E.D. Tex. 2001) (Cobb, J.) (โ[T]he Daubert inquiry is always fact-specific, and . . . the 
11 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 12 of 38 PageID #:  7666
Daubert factors may not all apply.โ).  Here, McAlear balanced his expertise about industry 
customs against sufficient information about Signalโs practices to reach the conclusion that 
Signalโs practices as to quality, the environment, the use of I.D. badges, and the issuance of 
personal protective equipment are โnormal and customaryโ within the industry.  (Doc. No. 150, 
Ex. C, p. 28.)  This type of analysis is sufficient to support McAlearโs opinions.   
g.  Conclusion 
  For  the  reasons  stated  above,  the  undersigned  GRANTS  IN  PART  the  Plaintiffsโ 
โMotion to Exclude Ron J. McAlear as Expertโ (Doc. No. 150).  McAlear may testify about 
general industry practices and opine on whether Signalโs practices are consistent with these 
customs.  McAlear, however, may not opine that Signal is a safe company or has an โexemplary 
safety record.โ

  Plaintiffs argue, โthe jurisdiction and coverage of OSHA prior to 2009 is not relevant to

b.  Milesโs opinion on whether certain OSHA regulations applied is helpful 
  Next, the Plaintiffs claim that Milesโs testimony will not be helpful because there is

the report served in this case and that served in David, but not requesting to have the additional 
                                                           
1.  The decision whether to allow a late filed expert reportโwhich is essentially why the Plaintiffs seek to

To  meet  the  first  prong  of  Rule  702,  โthe  expertโs  scientific,  technical,  or  other

and lacks such familiarity.  In addition, these hurricanes occurred nearly ten years agoโit is 
possible that memories have faded.  Accordingly, information regarding the housing market and

Furthermore, contested factual issues include why Signal allegedly forced the Plaintiffs to 
live in the โman campsโ and why Signal needed to use an immigrant labor force.  The state of the

c.  Sufficient facts and data  
  Dr. Gothamโs opinions can be broken into two general categories: (1) general opinions

also id. at p. 37) (โ[I]t is my opinion that the dearth of housing availability in Orange County, 
Texas . . . created a major obstacles for businesses in these areas to attract and keep the labor 
necessary for business and community recovery efforts.โ).  To reach such a specific opinion he 
would need to look at the housing market in an area in close proximity to Signalโs facility in 
Orange, Texas.  Dr. Gotham has undertaken no such analysis.  He did not consider specific data

d.  Conclusion 
For the reasons stated above, the Plaintiffsโ โMotion to Exclude Kevin Fox Gotham as 
Expertโ (Doc. No. 152) is GRANTED IN PART.  Dr. Gotham may opine about the state of

E.  Signalโs โMotion in Limine to Exclude/Limit Testimony of Florence Burkeโ (Doc. No. 
158) 
 
  Florence Burke (โBurkeโ) is the Plaintiffsโ expert on human trafficking.  She is offered to 
(1) โprovide the trier of fact with background on the H2-B guest worker visa program and on 
human trafficking in  generalโ and (2) โto demonstrate to the fact-finder that the facts and 
circumstances of this case as alleged by the Plaintiffs fit within the typical pattern of human 
trafficking.โ  (Doc. No. 181, p. 1.)  Signal argues that Burkeโs report should be struck for three 
reasons: (1) her report contains legal conclusions; (2) her opinions are unreliable; and (3) she is 
not qualified to render an opinion regarding the Plaintiffsโ mental state.  (Doc. No. 158.)  
a.  Permissible scope of expert testimony on human trafficking 
Courts  have  reached  varied  conclusions  on  whether  expert  testimony  on  human 
trafficking is admissible.  Compare Elat v. Ngoubene, 993 F. Supp. 2d 497, 514 (D. Md. 2014) 
(allowing some testimony about human trafficking) with (Doc. No. 2038, David v. Signal Intโl, 
L.L.C., No. 2:08-cv-1220 (E.D. La. Dec. 30, 2014) (striking all expert testimony on human 
trafficking)).  The issue is that in this context, it is difficult to delineate between an opinion that 
is merely a legal conclusion (i.e., that 18 U.S.C. ยง 1590 was violated) and testimony that 
educates the jury and may be helpful.  While Federal Rule of Evidence 704 โabolish[ed] the per 
se rule against testimony regarding ultimate issues of fact . . . [it] does not open the door to all 
opinions.โ  See Owen v. Kerr-McGee Corp., 698 F.2d 236, 241โ42 (5th Cir. 1983).  โThe 
Advisory Committee notes make it clear that questions which would merely allow the witness to 
tell the jury what result to reach are not permitted.  Nor is the rule intended to allow a witness to 
give legal conclusions.โ  Id.  โThe line between a permissible opinion on an ultimate issue and 
an impermissible legal conclusion is not always easy to discern.โ  United States v. McIver, 470 
F.3d 550, 562 (4th Cir. 2006).  
20 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 21 of 38 PageID #:  7675
In  delineating  the  proper  of  scope  of  expert  testimony  on  human  trafficking,  the 
undersigned must guard against two things.  First, an expert must not be allowed to instruct the 
jury on what the legal elements of human trafficking are (i.e., what is needed to prove a violation 
of 18 U.S.C. ยง 1590)โthat is the courtโs job.  Second, an expert must be prevented from telling 
the  jury  what  conclusion  to  reach  as  to  whether  the  Plaintiffs  were  victims  of  human 
traffickingโthat is for the jury to decide.  Therefore, the issue is how to delineate between a 
general  discussion  of  human  trafficking,  which  may  help  the  jury  better  understand  the 
complexities of human trafficking and is therefore admissible, and reaching a conclusion as to 
whether these Plaintiffs were victims of human trafficking, which would usurp the role of the 
jury.  This difficulty is further compounded by the fact that the term โhuman traffickingโ has 
both  a  legal  and  a  colloquial  meaning,  further  blurring  the  line  between  permissible  and 
impermissible testimony. 
The undersigned finds the appropriate balance to be as follows: Burke may testify about 
โhuman  trafficking  in  general,โ  which  includes  discussing  the  general  features  of  human 
trafficking schemes, but she may not offer an opinion on whether these Plaintiffs were victims of 
human trafficking.  This will allow Burke to educate and inform the jury on the subtleties of 
human  trafficking,  which  meets  the  helpfulness  requirement  of  Rule  702,  without  directly 
offering a legal conclusion.  FED. R. CIV. P. 702(a) (requiring that an expertโs specialized 
knowledge โhelp the trier of fact to understand the evidenceโ).  Moreover, allowing Burke to 
apply the facts of this case to her general standards would be tantamount to her telling the jury 
what conclusion to reach.  See also Elat, 993 F. Supp. 2d at 514 (striking portions of Burkeโs 
testimony, but allowing her to testify generally about โthe patterns of coercion and threats that 
21 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 22 of 38 PageID #:  7676
are  typically  present  in  situations  involving  the  exploitation  of  foreign  workersโ  and  other 
general topics relating to human trafficking). 
Two examples of the scope of permissible and impermissible testimony may be helpful.  
First, the portion of Burkeโs report where she offers background on human trafficking and 
discusses  โcommon  features  of  trafficking  situationsโ  is  permissible  because  it  is  purely 
informative.  (Doc. No. 158, Ex. A, p. 11.)  However, Burke cannot take the next logical step and 
conclude that there was trafficking in this case or opine on how the Plaintiffs were affected.  For 
example, she states:  โHaving considered Plaintiffsโ accounts of their trafficking experiences, it 
is my opinion that many of the trafficking factors identified above were present in Defendantsโ 
conduct towards them and operated to create a psychologically coercive environment in which a 
reasonable worker in the Plaintiffsโ situation would have felt compelled to continue working for 
Signal.โ  (Id. at p. 12.)  This is nothing more that her evaluating the facts and reaching a 
conclusion that there was traffickingโsuch an analysis is within the province of the jury.   
Second, Burke discusses in general terms how victims of human trafficking are often 
made  a  set  promises  about  what  their  working  conditions  will  be  like,  but  in  reality,  the 
conditions tend to be significantly worse.  (Id. at p. 19.)  This is within the scope of permissible 
testimony.  Burke, however, crosses the line by stating: โthe Plaintiffs in this case believe they 
were deceived and betrayed in terms of their employment conditions, living conditions, net 
wages, opportunity to work, overtime hours, and immigration status.โ  (Id. at pp. 19โ20.)  The 
jury, after hearing the facts, can evaluate whether the Plaintiffs were deceived. 
The  above  examples  are  not  the  only  places  where  Burkeโs  opinions  go  too  far.  
However, because her report is so intertwined with permissible and impermissible opinions, the 
undersigned will not attempt to state on a paragraph-by-paragraph (or sentence-by-sentence) 
22 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 23 of 38 PageID #:  7677
basis what is excluded from Burkeโs report.  The limitation that she may only opine about the 
characteristics of human trafficking in general, and not whether there was trafficking in this case, 
should suffice.      
b.  Signalโs other arguments 
  Signal  also  raises  several  other  arguments  as  to  why  Burkeโs  testimony  should  be 
excluded or limited.  First, Signal argues that Burke misrepresented two of her qualifications, 
and therefore should be struck.  (Doc. No. 158, pp. 2โ3.)  The undersigned disagrees.  A review 
of her experience and training shows Burke has extensive experience working with victims of 
human trafficking and is qualified to testify as an expert on human trafficking.  (See id., Ex. A, 
pp. 1โ5.)  Whether the school where she obtained her Ph.D. in clinical psychology is accredited 
by the American Psychological Association, or whether her license to be a family counselor in 
California is still valid, does not impact whether she is qualified as an expert on trafficking.  To 
the extent that Signal believes that these alleged misstatements affect the weight the jury should 
ascribe to her testimony, it can raise such issues on cross-examination.   
Next, Signal argues that Burkeโs report is unreliable because her interview process is 
flawed and that opinions based on Plaintiffsโ statements are inadmissible.  (Doc. No. 158, pp. 6โ
9.)  Because Burke is precluded from reaching an opinion on the issue of whether the Plaintiffs 
were victims of human trafficking, or evaluating the facts of this case as they relate to human 
trafficking, Signalโs argument is now moot.  (Id. at p. 9.)  Likewise, Signalโs argument that 
Burke is not competent to โreach a final diagnosisโ is no longer at issue, since she will not be

  The Plaintiffs argue that Dr. Shelleyโs report should be struck because it is โreplete with

human trafficking generally, this part of the Plaintiffsโ motion is now moot.  However, for 
clarity, the undersigned will address the Plaintiffsโ arguments.  First, the Plaintiffs claim that Dr.

condition of a debtor arising from a pledge by the debtor of his or her personal services or those

they did not learn that this promise had been made by the recruiters until after the workers 
arrived at Signal[โs] facilitiesโ  (Id. at p. 19); โThe Indian H2B workers did not have their 
passports or visas confiscatedโ (Id. at p. 38); and โ[i]n reviewing the thousands of Signal emails, 
I saw nothing in them reflecting any effort to economize on the workers or to shortchange them.โ  
(Id. at p. 41.)  These are just a few examples of many. 
  Because Dr. Shelleyโs opinions are limited to those related to the general characteristics 
of trafficking, such commentary on what the evidence establishes will not be allowed. 
c.  Reliability and methodology 
The Plaintiffs next argue, โ[f]or many of her opinions, Dr. Shelley asks this Court to 
make โscientifically unsupported leaps of faith in the causal chainโโ (Doc. No. 156, p. 9) (quoting 
Rider v. Sandoz Pharm. Corp., 295 F.3d 1194, 1202 (11th Cir. 2012)).  For example, they claim 
that Dr. Shelley supports her opinion that there was no trafficking in this case by erroneously 
drawing a conclusion from a report done by the Texas Task Force on Human Trafficking.  (Doc. 
No. 156, pp. 9โ10.)  Dr. Shelley may not opine as to whether there was trafficking in this case, 
and therefore, there is no need for her to discuss this report.  Moreover, after reviewing the report 
upon which Dr. Shelley relied, the undersigned agrees with the Plaintiffsโ assertion that Dr. 
Shelley is making too great a leap in claiming that this report actually absolves Signal of 
27 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 28 of 38 PageID #:  7682
trafficking.4  (See Doc. No. 180, Ex. B, p. 14) (opining that the โTexas State Task Force Report 
reveals that law enforcement authorities were working on trafficking in the region of Orange, 
Texas and both the Texas Task Force and the Bureau of Justice Statistics determined that the 
Signal case was not trafficking . . . .โ).  This report does not discuss this case, nor does it purport 
to be a discussion of all trafficking cases in Texas.  Furthermore, this is just one example; Dr. 
Shelley offers numerous โopinionsโ that are reached through a less than rigorous analysis.  
Because her testimony is limited to discussing the general features of human trafficking schemes, 
these portions of her report are no longer in the case.  However, because her report is replete with 
these types of remarks, the undersigned reiterates that any testimony given by Dr. Shelley at trial 
must meet the requirements of Rule 702.5 
d.  Dr. Shelley improperly assesses the witnessesโ credibility and character 
The Plaintiffs also seek to strike portions of Dr. Shelleyโs report where she assesses the 
credibility of the witnesses.  (Doc. No. 156, pp. 14โ15.)  Signal responds that Dr. Shelley is not 
passing on the witnessesโ credibility, but rather, merely elucidating the bases for her opinions.  
The undersigned is not persuaded.  (Doc. No. 180, p. 22.)  Dr. Shelley expressly opines about the 
character and truthfulness of certain witnesses.  For example, at her deposition she testified that 
Signal management had โgreat concernโ for the Indian workersโa sentiment that is echoed in 
her report.  The jury, without the assistance of Dr. Shelley, can evaluate whether this is true.  
                                                           
4.  See Office of the Attorney General, The Texas Response to Human Trafficking (2008), available at 
https://www.texasattorneygeneral.gov/cj/human-trafficking.      
 
5.  Dr. Shelley, particularly in the David report, which is the operative report, draws numerous conclusions 
derived from questionable analysis.  For example, Dr. Shelley opines, โ[e]xamining Slides 1, 2, and 3 of Signalโs 
safety performance reveals that is has an extremely low rate of accidents.โ  (Doc. No. 180, Ex. B, p. 35.)  As 
discussed above, reaching such a conclusion requires balancing Signalโs safety record against identifiable standards.  
See infra III.A.b.  In addition, she claims that the food was good and nutritious because she ate at a restaurant run by 
the same caterer years later.  (See Doc. No. 180, Ex. B, p. 28).     
 
28 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 29 of 38 PageID #:  7683
This is just one example of many. 6   Accordingly, Dr. Shelley may not opine as to the credibility, 
truthfulness, or character of any of the parties or witnesses in this case.  
e.  Dr. Shelleyโs testimony as it relates to Dewan is improper 
Dr. Shelley asserts in numerous places throughout her report that Dewan engaged in 
either deceptive or fraudulent practices.  (See, e.g., Doc. No. 180, Ex. B, pp. 9, 18โ19, 22, 26.)  
Such  testimony  is  improper  because  it  is  unhelpful.    Whether  Dewan  committed  fraud  or 
engaged in deceptive practices is something the jury can readily evaluate on their own after 
hearing the evidenceโthere is no need for expert testimony on this point.  Dr. Shelley cannot 
simply regurgitate Signalโs theory of the case through expert testimony.   Accordingly, Dr. 
Shelley shall be precluded from opining about Dewanโs conduct. 
f.  Conclusion 
  Much of Dr. Shelleyโs report consists of impermissible legal conclusions, advocacy, 
assessment of the witnessesโ credibility, and unreliable and unfounded opinions.  However, Dr. 
Shelley  does  devote  a  few  paragraphs  of  her  report  to  discussing  the  elements  of  human 
trafficking generally, and even opines that the Plaintiffsโ expert does not identify all elements 
that are โcentral to labor trafficking.โ  (Doc. No. 180, Ex. B, p. 35.)7  This portion of Shelleyโs 
report is acceptable; the remainder of Dr. Shelleyโs report is not. 
  Therefore, for the reasons stated above, the Plaintiffsโ โMotion to Exclude Dr. Louise 
Shelley as Expertโ (Doc. No. 156) is GRANTED IN PART.  Dr. Shelleyโs testimony is limited 
                                                           
6.  Some of the added material in the David report consists of Dr. Shelleyโs assessment of the certain 
statements.  (Doc. No. 180, Ex. B.)  For example, she states that โKurian Davidโs T-visa application is full of 
incorrect statementsโ (Id. at p. 21); โHemant Khuttanโs declaration raises many questions as to its veracity and the 
validity of his complaintsโ (Id. at 22); and she notes an alleged contradiction in Sony Vadusevan-Sulekhaโs 
statement by stating that โthe problem with his statement is that Signal never had any pictures of housing or 
residential facilities on its website.  This is a fantasy not reality.โ  (Id. at p. 23.)  Such โopinionsโ are improper. 
 
7.  These opinions, which are the only opinions that Dr. Shelley may offer, were also contained in the 
report served in this case.  (See, e.g., Doc. No. 156, Ex. B, pp. 15, 23.) 
29 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 30 of 38 PageID #:  7684
to a discussion of the general elements and characteristics of human trafficking.  She, however, 
may not opine on whether these Plaintiffs were victims of human trafficking, the credibility of 
the  Plaintiffs,  or  offer  her  assessment  of  the  facts  of  this  case.    Dewanโs  โMotion  and 
Incorporated  Memorandum  to  Exclude  Expert  Witness  Testimonyโ  (Doc.  No.  159)  is 
GRANTED, and Dr. Shelleyโs opinions as they relate to Dewan are struck. 
G.  The Plaintiffsโ โMotion to Limit the Testimony of Enrique Gonzalez, III as Expertโ 
(Doc. No. 155) and Burnettโs โMotion and Memorandum in Support to Exclude Legal 
Opinion Testimony of Signalโs Immigration Law Expertโ (Doc. No. 153) 
Signalโs expert, Enrique Gonzalez (โGonzalezโ), an immigration lawyer, โprepared a 
report addressing various ethical and U.S. immigration law issues as they pertain to the conduct 
of the various parties involved in this case.โ  (Doc. No. 155, Ex. A, p. 1.)  The Plaintiffs moved 
to strike Gonzalezโs opinion II and six other โstray remarks.โ  (Doc. No. 155, pp. 4โ7.)  Signal 
responded by arguing that Gonzalez was not โretained to provide an opinion on plaintiffsโ 
conduct in this case and concedes that he will not testify at trial to any individual plaintiffsโ 
conduct, nor that of any plaintiffs collectively.โ  (Doc. No. 176, p. 1.)  However, Signal claims 
that  Gonzalezโs  opinion  II  is  โessential  for  the  development  of  [his]  subsequent  opinions 
regarding Burnett.โ  (Id. at pp. 1โ2.)   
In addition, Burnett moved to exclude a large portion of Gonzalezโs report, arguing that it 
contains impermissible legal conclusions.  (Doc. No. 153.)  Signal responded and claimed that 
Gonzalezโs report was not โproffered to circumvent the fact finding role of the jury,โ but that 
โthe  facts  and  the  pertinent  regulations  are  so  intertwined  that  they  must  be  presented  in 
conjunction,โ and therefore, his opinions are admissible in their entirety.  (Doc. No. 175, p. 1.) 
 
 
30 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 31 of 38 PageID #:  7685
a.  Due to the severance and transfer of Signalโs cross-claims, Gonzalezโs opinions 
II-V are no longer relevant 
 
Gonzalez offers five opinions.  (Doc. No. 155, Ex. A.)  Because Signalโs cross-claims 
against Burnett and others were recently severed and transferred to  the Eastern  District  of 
Louisiana, opinions III through V are no longer relevant, and therefore, are inadmissible.  (Doc. 
No. 205.)  These opinions focus on duties owed by an immigration attorney to its client, and the 
standard of care that an immigration attorney should maintain.  In other words, they are aimed at 
supporting Signalโs claims against Burnett for malpractice and breach of fiduciary dutyโclaims 
that are no longer at issue in this case.  
In addition, the undersigned finds Gonzalezโs opinion II is not helpful, and therefore, 
inadmissible.  He opines that: โForeign nationals seeking an H-2B visa are considered to have 
committed immigration fraud if they deliberately conceal their intent to remain permanently in 
the United States from a U.S. consular or immigration officer.โ  (Doc. No. 155, Ex. A, p. 24.)  
There  is  no  cause  of  action  in  this  case  that  centers  on  whether  the  Plaintiffs  committed 
immigration fraud.  While Signal may argue that the Plaintiffs in fact concealed their true intent 
in applying for H-2B visas, there is no need for expert testimony opining as to whether this 
amounts to immigration fraud.  Signalโs primary argument that opinion II should not be struck is 
that it is โessential for the development of Gonzalezโs subsequent opinions regarding Burnett.โ  
(Doc. No. 176, pp. 1โ2.)  However, these subsequent opinions have been struck, therefore, this 
argument is without merit.   
Accordingly, the undersigned strikes opinions II-V. 
b.  Other โstray remarksโ are inadmissible 
The Plaintiffs also move to exclude six other โstray remarksโ that they claim are aimed at 
them and are impermissible.  Two examples are illustrative.  First, Gonzalez states: โThe intent 
31 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 32 of 38 PageID #:  7686
by  the  foreign  nationals  and  other  companies  was  for  the  workers  to  remain  in  the  U.S. 
permanently.โ  (Doc. No. 155, Ex. A, p. 14.)  Second, by โcounseling foreign nationals to lie to 
immigration officers about their intent to remain in the U.S., Mr. Burnett, as well as the foreign 
nationals, knowingly committed immigration fraud.โ  (Id. at p. 15.) 
It appears that Gonzalez is inferring that the Plaintiffs committed these acts, even though  
Gonzalez unequivocally testified that he is not offering any opinions on the Plaintiffsโ conduct.  
(Doc. No. 155, Ex. B, 191:6โ13.)  There is simply no other way to interpret his assertion that 
โthe  foreign  nationalsโ  (i.e.,  the  Plaintiffs)  โknowingly  committed  immigration  fraudโ  by 
allegedly  lying  about  their  intent.    Therefore,  to  prevent  any  unnecessary  confusion  that 
Gonzalez is opining about the Plaintiffsโ conduct, these remarks are struck.  Moreover, these 
remarks are offered in Gonzalezโs report to illustrate how Burnett allegedly breached his duties.  
Because opinions about Burnettโs duties as an immigration lawyer are no longer relevant to this 
case, there is no need for such stray remarks.  Accordingly, the Plaintiffsโ motion is granted.   
c.  Gonzalezโs opinion I 
All that remains is Gonzalezโs opinion I, in which he states: โit is not immigration fraud 
to indicate to the U.S. government that the need for H2-B workers is on a temporary basis, and 
then to seek an extension after extreme natural disasters like Hurricanes Rita and Katrina.โ  
(Doc. No. 155, Ex. A, p. 24.)  The Plaintiffs do not take issue with this opinion.  Moreover, 
Burnett does not specifically argue that this opinion should be struck, but rather claims generally 
that โthis Court should limit any testimony by Plaintiffsโ and Signalโs experts to the general 
process for obtaining non-immigrant visas and permanent work resident visasโ and not allow 
experts to offer โany legal opinion as to what the law is or whether or not any applicable laws or 
regulations were breached by anyone.โ  (Doc. No. 153, p. 11.)  
32 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 33 of 38 PageID #:  7687
  Opinion I straddles the line between being a legal conclusion and helpful testimony on 
the immigration process generally.   On the one hand, Gonzalez should be prevented from 
testifying  outright  that  Signal  did  not  commit  immigration  fraud.    This  would  be  a  legal 
conclusion.    However,  looking  at  this  opinion  within  in  the  context  of  Gonzalezโs  report, 
Gonzalez does not do this.  This opinion is contained in the background section of his report, and 
is part of his discussion of the immigration process generally.  Moreover, he never actually 
concludes that Signal did not commit immigration fraud (even though that is what can be 
inferred).  Therefore, opinion I is proper.  While Gonzalezโs opinion comes close to offering a 
legal conclusion, it is not inadmissible.  At trial, however, the parties will need to be vigilant to 
ensure that the phrasing of any questions do not elicit a pure legal conclusion.  See, e.g., Owen, 
698 F.2d at 240 (discussing that the way a question is phrased may elicit an improper legal 
conclusion) (citing FED. R. EVID. 704 advisory committeeโs notes).   
d.  Conclusion 
Because Signalโs cross-claims have been transferred, the undersigned strikes opinions III-
V of Gonzalezโs report as irrelevant.  The Plaintiffsโ โMotion to Limit the Testimony of Enrique 
Gonzalez, III as Expertโ (Doc. No. 155) is GRANTED and the undersigned strikes Gonzalezโs 
opinion II.  Moreover, the six โstray remarksโ identified by the Plaintiffs are also struck, and 
Gonzalez  is  precluded  from  offering  testimony  that  appears  to  opine  about  the  Plaintiffsโ 
conduct.  Burnettโs โMotion and Memorandum in Support to Exclude Legal Opinion Testimony 
of Signalโs Immigration Law Expertโ (Doc. No. 153) is GRANTED IN PART and Gonzalez 
may  not  offer  โany  testimony  as  to  his  opinions  of  the  law, . . .  [or]  opinions[,] . . . legal 
conclusions[,] or interpretation of what the evidence establishes.โ  Gonzalez may, however, 
discuss the H2-B visa program generally and the general process for obtaining such visas.  
33 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 34 of 38 PageID #:  7688
H.  Signalโs โMotion in Limine to Exclude/Limit Testimony of Amy Mowlโ (Doc. No. 157) 
  Signal moves to exclude or limit the testimony of the Plaintiffsโ expert, Amy Mowl.  
(Doc. No. 157.)  Mowl is an economist, and is currently on the faculty of the Institute for 
Financial  Management  and  Research  Business  School  in  Chennai,  India.    The  Plaintiffs 
designated Mowl to provide โa culturally specific socio-economic context to assist the jury in 
understanding the nature of the debts incurred by Plaintiffs in India to pay hefty recruitment fees 
charged by Defendants.โ  (Doc. No. 182, p. 1.)  Signal seeks to exclude or limit Mowlโs 
testimony on three grounds: (1) she makes impermissible credibility determinations; (2) her 
testimony regarding suicide must be limited; and (3) โMowl uses insufficient information and 
unreliable principles or methods in forming her opinions.โ  (Doc. No. 157.) 
a.  Credibility Determination 
  Signal argues that Mowl passes on the credibility of the Plaintiffsโ statements, and that 
her โopinions impermissibly regurgitate[] the Plaintiffsโ testimony stamped with the imprimatur 
of  her  expertise.โ    (Doc.  No.  157,  p.  5.)    The  undersigned  disagrees  with  Signalโs 
characterization of Mowlโs approach.  Mowl testified that she received sworn statements made 
by the Plaintiffs, and because they were sworn, assumed they were true.  (Id., Ex. B, 46:19โ
47:16.)    In  addition,  when  questioned  about  whether  she  examined  the  truthfulness  of  the 
Plaintiffsโ statements, she said she did not because they were consistent with what she knows 
about Indian finance products.  (Id.)  This is not the same as opining that the statements are in 
fact true.   
  Signal attempts to argue that Mowlโs opinions are similar to ones that were struck in Elat 
v. Ngoubene.  (Doc. No. 157, p. 5.)  In Elat, the expert weighed two competing sets of facts, and 
concluded that the plaintiffโs version of the facts was more credible than the defendantsโ.  Elat, 
34 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 35 of 38 PageID #:  7689
993 F. Supp. 2d at 513โ14 (noting that the expertโs โevaluation of the truthfulness of Plaintiffโs 
version of the underlying events as compared to Defendantsโ is little different from the way that 
juries themselves determine credibility from conflicting testimony.โ).  The expert then used the 
plaintiffโs version of the facts as the basis for her opinion.  Id.  Mowl did not undertake such an 
analysis.  She merely took the plaintiffsโ statements at face value and felt she could because they 
were consistent with what she expected based on her experience.  This is the same as forming an 
opinion based on documents produced in discovery.  
b.  Testimony regarding suicide8 
To illustrate the effect that debts can have on people in India, Mowl discusses a recent 
wave of suicides by Indian farm workers.  (Doc. No. 157, Ex. A, pp. 17โ20.)  Signal seeks to 
exclude this part of Mowlโs report on two grounds.  First, Signal argues that her sources are 
faulty.  Mowlโs sources were Indian newspapers.  Signal has pointed to no reason why the 
reliability or truthfulness of these sources should be doubted.  Moreover, this type of challenge 
goes to the weight that the fact finder should ascribe to the opinions, not their admissibility.  See 
14.38 Acres of Land, 80 F.3d at 1077 (โAs a general rule, questions relating to the bases and 
sources of an expertโs opinion affect the weight to be assigned that opinion rather than its 
admissibility and should be left for the juryโs consideration.โ).   
Second, Signal claims that Mowl has not offered any form of โpeer-reviewed or other 
authoritative sourceโ showing that suicide rates amongst the farming community are relevant or 
similar to those amongst the non-farming community.  (Doc. No. 157, p. 6); see also Daubert, 
509 U.S. at 592โ93 (noting that one of the indicia of reliability is whether the expertโs theory or 
technique has been subject to peer review).  While courts have struck expert testimony when 
there is too large of an analytic gap, the undersigned does not find that such a gap exists here.  
                                                           
8.  Signal did not argue that such testimony may be unfairly prejudicial.  See FED. R. EVID. 403.  
35 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 36 of 38 PageID #:  7690
See also Pipitone, 288 F.3d at 244 (discussing that โthe factors identified in Daubert may or may 
not pertinent in assessing reliabilityโ).  Mowl does not need to show a direct correlation between 
farm worker and non-farm worker suicide rates to draw an analogy.  Furthermore, Signal has 
pointed to no studies that Mowl has ignored, and the undersigned finds it unlikely that such 
studies have ever been conducted.  
c.  Sufficiency of information and reliability of principles 
Signal next argues that Mowl has not reviewed sufficient information.  Signal faults her 
for โnot consider[ing] the pay data produced by Signal as part of its ESI productions,โ โfailing to 
request any banking records,โ and not reviewing the deposition of Sachin Dewan.  (Doc. No. 
157, pp. 6โ8.)  The undersignedโs role, however, is to ensure that expert testimony is โbased on 
sufficient facts or dataโโnot to ensure that an expert left no stone unturned.  FED. R. EVID. 702.  
Here, after reviewing her report, the undersigned finds that Mowl has met this threshold.  Mowl 
lists  over  forty  sources  that  she  considered  in  drafting  her  report.    Also,  a  review  of  her 
deposition  shows  that  she  had  cogent  reasons  for  choosing  not  to  review  certain  sources.  
Furthermore, an argument that an expert โdid not review sufficient fats and data goes to the 
weight of [its] opinion, to be brought out in cross-examination and resolved by the jury, not to 
admissibility.โ  Suzion Wind Energy Corp. v. Shippers Stevedoring Co., 662 F. Supp. 2d 623, 
667 (S.D. Tex. 2009).  
d.  Conclusion 
Accordingly, Signalโs โMotion in Limine to Exclude/Limit Testimony of Amy Mowlโ 
(Doc. No. 157) is DENIED. 
 
 
36 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 37 of 38 PageID #:  7691
IV. Conclusion 
  The undersigned finds as follows: 
๏ท  The  Plaintiffsโ  โMotion  to  Exclude  Ron  J.  McAlear  as  Expertโ  (Doc.  No.  150)  is 
GRANTED IN PART.  McAlear may testify about general industry practices and opine 
as to whether Signalโs practices are consistent with these customs.  However, McAlear 
may not opine that Signal is a safe company or has an โexemplary safety recordโ; 
   
๏ท  The  Plaintiffsโ  โMotion  to  Exclude  Virginia  Miles  as  Expertโ  (Doc.  No.  151)  is 
DENIED; 
 
๏ท  The Plaintiffsโ โMotion to Exclude Donald H. Strobel as Expertโ (Doc. No. 154) is 
GRANTED subject to reconsideration should the court at a later time allow the Plaintiffs 
to file FLSA claims in this case; 
 
๏ท  The Plaintiffsโ โMotion to Exclude Kevin Fox Gotham as Expertโ (Doc. No. 152) is 
GRANTED IN PART.  Dr. Gotham may opine about the state of housing in Orange, 
Texas in general and the correlation between available housing and attracting skilled 
workers (opinions A through D).  However, opinions E and F are struck, and he may not 
opine as to whether there was โan acuteโ housing shortage in Orange, Texas, why Signal 
built the โman camp,โ whether the Plaintiffs were required or coerced into living at the 
โman camp,โ or whether the โman campโ actually benefited the Plaintiffs; 
 
๏ท  Signalโs โMotion in Limine to Exclude/Limit Testimony of Florence Burkeโ (Doc. No. 
158) is GRANTED IN PART.  Burkeโs opinions shall be limited to those related to 
general  characteristics  of  human  trafficking  schemes,  and  Burke  is  precluded  from 
testifying as to whether these Plaintiffs were victims of human trafficking or in what 
ways the facts of this case are similar to other known cases of human trafficking; 
 
๏ท  The Plaintiffsโ โMotion to Exclude Dr. Louise Shelley as Expertโ (Doc. No. 156) is 
GRANTED IN PART.  Dr. Shelleyโs testimony is limited to a discussion of the general 
elements and characteristics of human trafficking, and she may not opine on whether 
these Plaintiffs were victims of human trafficking, the credibility of the Plaintiffs, or offer 
her assessment of the facts of this case; 
 
๏ท  Defendants Sachin Dewan and Dewan Consultants Pvt. Ltd.โs โMotion and Incorporated 
Memorandum to Exclude Expert Witness Testimonyโ (Doc. No. 159) is GRANTED and 
the undersigned strikes Dr. Shelleyโs opinions about Dewan; 
 
๏ท  The Plaintiffsโ โMotion to Limit the Testimony of Enrique Gonzalez, III as Expertโ (Doc. 
No. 155) is GRANTED.  The undersigned strikes Opinion II and the six other identified 
โstray remarksโ identified by the Plaintiffs;  
   
37 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 222   Filed 02/12/15   Page 38 of 38 PageID #:  7692
๏ท  Burnettโs โMotion and Memorandum in Support to Exclude Legal Opinion Testimony of 
Signalโs Immigration Law Expertโ (Doc. No. 153) is GRANTED IN PART and the 
undersigned strikes opinions III-V.  Moreover, Gonzalez may not offer any testimony as 
to his opinions of the law, or opinions, legal conclusions, or interpretation of what the 
evidence establishes.  Gonzalez may, however, discuss the H2-B visa program generally 
and the general process for obtaining such visas;  
 
๏ท  Signalโs โMotion in Limine to Exclude/Limit Testimony of Amy Mowlโ (Doc. No. 157) 
is DENIED. 
 
V. Objections 
Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 636(b)(1)(c) (Supp. IV 2011), each party to this action has the 
right  to  file objections to  this order.  Objections to  this  order must (1) be in  writing, (2) 
specifically identify those findings or recommendations to which the party objects, (3) be served 
and filed within fourteen (14) days after being served with a copy of this report; and (4) be no 
more than five pages in length.9  See 28 U.S.C. ยง 636(b)(1)(A); FED R. CIV. P. 72(a); Local Rule 
CV-72(b).  If timely objections are made, the district court judge will โmodify or set aside any 
part of the order that is clearly erroneous or is contrary to law.  See 28 U.S.C. ยง 636(b)(1)(A); 
Fed R. Civ. P. 72(a).   
 
SIGNED this 12th day of February, 2015.
__________________________________________________
Zaacckk HHaawwtthhoorrnn
United States Magistrate Judge
                                                           
9.  The local rules limit objections to a non-dispostive order to five pages.  See Local Rule CV-72(b).  
Should any party need additional pages, they must file a motion for leave to exceed page limits. 
38

documents.text:
Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 344   Filed 07/07/17   Page 1 of 4 PageID #:  9853
        
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
BEAUMONT DIVISION 
 
BIJU MUKRUKKATTU JOSEPH, et al.,   )   
  )   
  Plaintiffs,  )   
v.  )  Civ. No.  1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH 
    )   
SIGNAL INTERNATIONAL LLC, et al.,   )   
  )   
  Defendants.  )   
 
SIXTH STATUS REPORT 
Plaintiffs, in accordance with the Courtโs Order Staying Case Pursuant to Bankruptcy 
[Dkt. No. 335] requiring the parties to file a notice every 120 days informing the Court of the 
status of the Signal bankruptcy proceedings, hereby file this Status Report as of July 7, 2017.  
(Prior reports have been from all parties, but counsel for a defendant in this action has noted lack 
of  current  involvement  in  Signalโs  bankruptcy  proceedings,  so  counsel  for  Plaintiffs  is 
responsible for this report.) 
As noted in the partiesโ prior reports [Dkt. Nos. 338, 339, 340, 341 and 343], the Signal 
Entities filed voluntary petitions for relief under Chapter 11 of Title 11 of the United States Code 
on July 12, 2015.  In re Signal Intโl, Inc, et al., No. 15-11498 (Bankr. D. Del. July 12, 2015) (the 
โBankruptcy Courtโ).1  On November 24, 2015, the Bankruptcy Court entered its Findings of 
Fact,  Conclusions  of  Law  and  Order  Confirming  Debtorsโ  First  Amended  Joint  Plan  of 
Liquidation Pursuant to Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code [ECF No. 555] (the โConfirmation 
                                                 
1 The other entities are:  Signal Ship Repair, LLC (Case No. 15-11499), Signal Intโl, LLC (Case 
No. 15-11500), Signal Intโl Texas GP, LLC (Case No. 15-11501), and Signal Intโl Texas, L.P. 
(Case  No.  15-11502).    By  the  Bankruptcy  Courtโs  order,  all  five  cases  are  being  jointly 
administered with the Signal Intโl, Inc. case.  In re Signal Intโl, Inc., No. 15-11498 (Bankr. D. 
Del. July 14, 2015), ECF No. 55. 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 344   Filed 07/07/17   Page 2 of 4 PageID #:  9854
Orderโ), confirming the Signal Entitiesโ plan of liquidation, which implemented the plan support 
agreement among the Plaintiffs, the Signal Entities and certain other parties, for the settlement 
of, inter alia, the Plaintiffsโ claims against the relevant Signal Entities.  Pursuant to the Plan, a 
litigation  trust  (the  โSignal  Litigation  Trustโ)  has  been  created  for  the  distribution  of  the 
settlement proceeds.  That process remains ongoing, as the Signal Litigation Trust distributed 
Trust Claim Forms in February, 2016.  Initial partial payments on accepted claims have been 
distributed this month.   
The Plan became effective on December 14, 2015 [Bankr. Dkt. No. 589].  As of that date, 
pursuant to the Confirmation Order, โany suit, legal action, or other proceeding โฆ in any forum 
in the United States that is released, stayed, or enjoined pursuant to Article XI of the Plan against 
or affecting any Released Party [the Signal Entities], shall be stayed, enjoined or otherwise 
prohibited from continuation as to any Released Party.โ  (Confirmation Order at 25.) 
In light of the entry of the Confirmation Order, the Plaintiffs respectfully request that the 
stay remain in effect.  Pursuant to the Courtโs Order on July 14, 2015 [Dkt. No. 335], Plaintiffs 
will file a further status update in 120 days. 
 
[signatures on following page] 
2 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 344   Filed 07/07/17   Page 3 of 4 PageID #:  9855
Respectfully submitted, this 7th day of July, 2017.   
 
/s/ John H. Fleming         
John H. Fleming (pro hac vice) 
Travis J. Mock (pro hac vice) 
Kara D. Ford (pro hac vice) 
Heather M. Niemeyer (pro hac vice) 
Matthew J. Bowness (pro hac vice) 
 
EVERSHEDS SUTHERLAND (US) LLP  
999 Peachtree Street NE, Suite 2300 
Atlanta, Georgia  30309-3996 
Telephone:  (404) 853-8000 
Facsimile:   (404) 853-8806 
johnfleming@eversheds-sutherland.com 
travismock@eversheds-sutherland.com 
karaford@eversheds-sutherland.com 
heatherniemeyer@eversheds-sutherland.com 
matthewbowness@eversheds-sutherland.com 
 
 
ATTORNEYS FOR PLAINTIFFS 
3 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 344   Filed 07/07/17   Page 4 of 4 PageID #:  9856
 
CERTIFICATE OF SERVICE 
I hereby certify that on July 7, 2017, I electronically filed the foregoing Sixth Status 
Report with the Clerk of Court using the CM/ECF system, which will automatically send e-mail 
notification of such filing to all ECF participants. 
I further certify that on July 7, 2017 I served a true and correct copy of the foregoing 
document upon the below-named Defendants by depositing a copy of same in the U.S. Mail, 
with sufficient postage thereon to insure delivery, and properly addressed as follows: 
Michael Pol 
Global Resources, Inc. 
c/o William P. Wessler, Esq. 
William P. Wessler, Attorney at Law 
1624 24th Avenue 
Gulfport, MS  39501-2969 
Mr. Billy Wilks 
9136 Heather Lane 
Moss Point, MS 39562 
 
 
 
/s/ John H. Fleming   
John H. Fleming

documents.title: Seventh Status Report
documents.text:
Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 345   Filed 11/06/17   Page 1 of 4 PageID #:  9857
        
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
BEAUMONT DIVISION 
 
BIJU MUKRUKKATTU JOSEPH, et al.,   )   
  )   
  Plaintiffs,  )   
v.  )  Civ. No.  1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH 
    )   
SIGNAL INTERNATIONAL LLC, et al.,   )   
  )   
  Defendants.  )   
 
SEVENTH STATUS REPORT 
Plaintiffs, in accordance with the Courtโs Order Staying Case Pursuant to Bankruptcy 
[Dkt. No. 335] requiring the parties to file a notice every 120 days informing the Court of the 
status of the Signal bankruptcy proceedings, hereby file this Status Report as of November 6, 
2017.  (Reports prior to the Sixth Report were from all parties, but counsel for a Defendant in 
this action noted lack of current involvement in Signalโs bankruptcy proceedings, so counsel for 
Plaintiffs is responsible for this report.) 
As noted in the partiesโ prior reports [Dkt. Nos. 338, 339, 340, 341, 343, and 344], the 
Signal Entities filed voluntary petitions for relief under Chapter 11 of Title 11 of the United 
States Code on July 12, 2015.  In re Signal Intโl, Inc, et al., No. 15-11498 (Bankr. D. Del. July 
12, 2015) (the โBankruptcy Courtโ).1  On November 24, 2015, the Bankruptcy Court entered its 
Findings of Fact, Conclusions of Law and Order Confirming Debtorsโ First Amended Joint Plan 
of  Liquidation  Pursuant  to  Chapter  11  of  the  Bankruptcy  Code  [ECF  No.  555]  (the 
                                                 
1 The other entities are:  Signal Ship Repair, LLC (Case No. 15-11499), Signal Intโl, LLC (Case 
No. 15-11500), Signal Intโl Texas GP, LLC (Case No. 15-11501), and Signal Intโl Texas, L.P. 
(Case  No.  15-11502).    By  the  Bankruptcy  Courtโs  order,  all  five  cases  are  being  jointly 
administered with the Signal Intโl, Inc. case.  In re Signal Intโl, Inc., No. 15-11498 (Bankr. D. 
Del. July 14, 2015), ECF No. 55. 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 345   Filed 11/06/17   Page 2 of 4 PageID #:  9858
โConfirmation Orderโ), confirming the Signal Entitiesโ plan of liquidation, which implemented 
the plan support agreement among the Plaintiffs, the Signal Entities and certain other parties, for 
the settlement of, inter alia, the Plaintiffsโ claims against the relevant Signal Entities.  Pursuant 
to the Plan, a litigation trust (the โSignal Litigation Trustโ) has been created for the distribution 
of  the  settlement  proceeds.    That  process  remains  ongoing,  as  the  Signal  Litigation  Trust 
distributed Trust Claim Forms in February, 2016.  Initial partial payments on accepted claims 
were distributed in July, 2017.   
The Plan became effective on December 14, 2015 [Bankr. Dkt. No. 589].  As of that date, 
pursuant to the Confirmation Order, โany suit, legal action, or other proceeding โฆ in any forum 
in the United States that is released, stayed, or enjoined pursuant to Article XI of the Plan against 
or affecting any Released Party [the Signal Entities], shall be stayed, enjoined or otherwise 
prohibited from continuation as to any Released Party.โ  (Confirmation Order at 25.) 
In light of the entry of the Confirmation Order, the Plaintiffs respectfully request that the 
stay remain in effect.  Pursuant to the Courtโs Order on July 14, 2015 [Dkt. No. 335], Plaintiffs 
will file a further status update in 120 days. 
 
[signatures on following page] 
2

/s/ John H. Fleming

ATTORNEYS FOR PLAINTIFFS

I further certify that on November 6, 2017, I served a true and correct copy of the

documents.title: Order on Limitations of Trial Time
documents.text:
Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 286   Filed 03/17/15   Page 1 of 4 PageID #:  8806
  IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
BEAUMONT DIVISION 
 
BIJU MAKRUKKATTU JOSEPH 
'   
   
'   
V.  ' 
CASE NO.:  1:13-CV-324 (RC) 
  ' 
SIGNAL INTERNATIONAL, LLC, ET AL  ' 
' 
 
ORDER ON LIMITATIONS OF TRIAL TIME 
 
This case is set for a final pretrial hearing on April 2, 2015, with trial on April 6, 2015. The 
court gave the parties notice that it would impose time limits on the presentation of their cases at 
trial.  The court has reviewed the submissions of the parties and for the reasons stated allots time 
as follows: 
It  has  long  been  recognized  by  trial  lawyers,  that  โ[a]  shorter  trial  promotes  jury 
comprehension.โ Manual for Complex Litigation (Fourth) ยง 12.3 (2004). The Federal Rules of 
Procedure โshould be construed and administered to secure the just, speedy, and inexpensive 
determination of every action and proceeding.โ Fed. R. Civ. P. 1.  โA trial court is required to 
โexercise reasonable control over the mode and order of interrogating witnesses and presenting 
evidenceโ in order to ensure that evidence is presented effectively for the ascertainment of truth, 
time is conserved, and witnesses are protected from harassment.  See Fed. R. Evid. 611(a).โ  
United States v. Hill, 643 F.3d 807, 845 (11th Cir. 2011). 
โ[M]any jurors expect information to be presented succinctly, even where it deals with 
complex matters.โ Manual for Complex Litigation (Fourth) ยง 12.3 (2004). This court is well aware 
that many lawyers fear that jurors may not have understood a point the first, third, fifth, or tenth 
time it is mentioned.  But the undersigned has met with the jury in each case tried in this court.  
 
  Page 1 of  4 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 286   Filed 03/17/15   Page 2 of 4 PageID #:  8807
Invariably a juror asks โwhy do the lawyers keep repeating themselves?โ As one juror commented 
to the undersigned, โI am a teacher. I understand the rule about โtell an audience what you plan to 
tell them, tell them, and then tell them what you told them.โ That is three times.  We donโt need to 
hear it ten times.โ   
Essentially the same case has been tried once against these Defendants in New Orleans.  
So, counsel should be familiar with what testimony will be presented and how it may be 
summarized.  Counsel are expected to be familiar with Fed. R. Evid. 1006 and the savings in time 
that can be achieved by use of skillfully prepared summaries, as well as charts, timelines, diagrams 
and photos. See William W. Schwarzer, Reforming Jury Trials , 132 F.R.D. 575, 578 (1991).  
Counsel should also consider  approved time saving techniques such as:  the use of properly 
prepared affidavits to support the admission of those business records for which there is no 
agreement as to authenticity;   using an expertโs rรฉsumรฉ as an exhibit to save time on his 
introduction;  submission of extracts of voluminous exhibits containing only  the pertinent 
pages; and  proper use of the time allowed for interim statements to quickly transition between 
topics, and to inform jurors about expected testimony.  
Jurors shall be provided with a notebook to aid in their comprehension of the case. Counsel 
should discuss:  definitions of terms, diagrams, key exhibits, timelines, etc. for inclusion in juror 
notebooks.  Parties shall cooperate in providing the court with a page for each sideโs witnesses, 
containing a photograph of the witness (about 3" x 3") with the witnessโs name, title (or position, if 
employed by a party), and space for jurors to take notes, for inclusion in each  juror notebook;  
See Manual for Complex Litigation (Fourth) ยงยง 12.3, 12.31, 12.32, 12.422 (2004) 
Time was requested for experts to opine on the law of immigration and other topics. The court 
will determine what law applies to the case and instruct the jury on the law as necessary.  Expert 
 
  Page 2 of  4 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 286   Filed 03/17/15   Page 3 of 4 PageID #:  8808
testimony on the law of immigration and on most other topics  is not appropriate. See, e.g., 
Askanase v. Fatjo, 130 F.3d 657, 673 (5th Cir. 1997); Thompson v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 34 
F.3d 932, 941 (10th Cir. 1994); Specht v. Jensen, 853 F.2d 805 (10th Cir. 1988), cert. denied, 488 
U.S. 1008 (1989). 
The court=s decision is based in part upon requests for time for more than one expert on a 
single topic and time for several witnesses concerning the same limited facts. Such testimony is 
repetitive  at  best,  and  confusing  and  contradictory  at  worst.    See  William  W.  Schwarzer, 
Reforming Jury Trials, 132 F.R.D. 575, 578 (1991). 
The parties were ordered to provide the court with estimates of time needed for trial.  The 
Order specified the information required, and stated that the estimates could be provided in camera 
so as not to reveal trial strategy.  In many instances, parties chose to ignore the order and failed to 
describe the topic of expected testimony.  Therefore, these requests were discounted.  Defendant 
Billy R. Wilks chose to ignore the Courtโs order and failed to submit an estimate, so the Court must 
base its decision on information provided by the other parties. 
It is further ORDERED that Plaintiffs will be allowed 36 hours, whether used in direct 
examination or cross examination.  Defendants Signal International, LLC, Signal International, 
Inc., Signal International Texas, G.P., and Signal International Texas, L.P. (as a group) will be 
allowed 28 hours; Defendants Sachin Dewan and Dewan Consultants PVT.LTD (as a group) will 
be allowed 8 hours; and Defendants Malvern C. Barnett, Law Offices of Malvern C. Burnett, 
A.P.C., and Gulf Coast Immigration Law Center, LLC (as a group) will be allowed 8 hours, 
whether used in direct examination or cross examination.  Plaintiffs and Defendants shall each 
have 10 minutes for interim statements, to be used not for argument or summation, but to inform 
the jury about anticipated testimony, or to direct the jury=s attention to the fact that a new topic is 
 
  Page 3 of  4 

Case 1:13-cv-00324-RC-ZJH   Document 286   Filed 03/17/15   Page 4 of 4 PageID #:  8809
about to be discussed. For example, after covering invalidity contentions with an expert, counsel 
might say something like: ALadies and Gentlemen, that completes Dr. Smith=s testimony about  
the invalidity of both patents (the necessary treatment of Plaintiff).   He will now discuss  Dr. 
Howardโs testimony about infringement of the โ109 patent (the reasonable and necessary costs of 
Plaintiffโs treatment)โ. 
A party may, at the conclusion of 80% of its allotted time, move for an extension of time.  
Such extension will only be granted for good cause shown, and such good cause shall include a 
showing that the party=s past use of time and anticipated use of remaining and requested time does 
not constitute undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence. 
 
 
  Page 4 of  4
